3PARA RAT.Name: 3PARA RAT
3PARA RAT.Description: 3PARA RAT is a remote access tool (RAT) programmed in C++ that has been used by Putter Panda. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT will use an 8-byte XOR key derived from the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS instead if the DES decoding fails.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT has a command to retrieve metadata for files on disk as well as a command to list the current working directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT will sleep until after a date/time value loaded from a .dat file has passed. This allows the RAT to remain dormant until a set date, which could allow a means to regain access if other parts of the actors' toolset are removed from a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT command and control commands are encrypted within the HTTP C2 channel using the DES algorithm in CBC mode with a key derived from the MD5 hash of the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: 3PARA RAT has a command to set certain attributes such as creation/modification timestamps on files.[1]

4H RAT.Name: 4H RAT
4H RAT.Description: 4H RAT is malware that has been used by Putter Panda since at least 2007. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT has the capability to create a remote shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT has the capability to obtain a listing of running processes (including loaded modules).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: 4H RAT sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.[1]

adbupd.Name: adbupd
adbupd.Description: adbupd is a backdoor used by PLATINUM that is similar to Dipsind. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: adbupd can run a copy of cmd.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: adbupd contains a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt C2 traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Techniques Used.Use: adbupd can use a WMI script to achieve persistence.[1]

Adups.Name: Adups
Adups.Description: Adups is software that was pre-installed onto Android devices, including those made by BLU Products. The software was reportedly designed to help a Chinese phone manufacturer monitor user behavior, transferring sensitive data to a Chinese server. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Adups transmitted call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Adups transmitted contact lists.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Adups transmitted the full contents of text messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Adups transmitted location information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Adups was pre-installed on Android devices from some vendors.[1][2]

ADVSTORESHELL.Name: ADVSTORESHELL
ADVSTORESHELL.Description: ADVSTORESHELL is a spying backdoor that has been used by APT28 from at least 2012 to 2016. It is generally used for long-term espionage and is deployed on targets deemed interesting after a reconnaissance phase. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can create a remote shell and run a given command.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: A variant of ADVSTORESHELL attempts communication to the C2 server over HTTP on port 443.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Some variants of ADVSTORESHELL achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL compresses output data generated by command execution with a custom implementation of the Lempel–Ziv–Welch (LZW) algorithm.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: C2 traffic from ADVSTORESHELL is encrypted, then encoded with Base64 encoding.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL encrypts with the 3DES algorithm and a hardcoded key prior to exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL stores output from command execution in a .dat file in the %TEMP% directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL exfiltrates data over the same channel used for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can list files and directories.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can delete files and directories.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can perform keylogging.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL is capable of setting and deleting Registry values.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Most of the strings in ADVSTORESHELL are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed. API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can list connected devices.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can list running processes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can enumerate registry keys.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL has used rundll32.exe in a Registry value to establish persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL collects, compresses, encrypts, and exfiltrates data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL connects to port 80 of a C2 server using Wininet API.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: A variant of ADVSTORESHELL encrypts some C2 with 3DES and RSA.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ADVSTORESHELL can run Systeminfo to gather information about the victim.[2][3]

Agent.btz.Name: Agent.btz
Agent.btz.Description: Agent.btz is a worm that primarily spreads itself via removable devices such as USB drives. It reportedly infected U.S. military networks in 2008. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz saves system information into an XML file that is then XOR-encoded.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz creates a file named thumb.dd on all USB flash drives connected to the victim. This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz attempts to download an encrypted binary from a specified domain.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz collects the network adapter’s IP and MAC address as well as IP addresses of the network adapter’s default gateway, primary/secondary WINS, DHCP, and DNS servers, and saves them into a log file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Agent.btz obtains the victim username and saves it to a file.[2]

Allwinner.Name: Allwinner
Allwinner.Description: Allwinner is a company that supplies processors used in Android tablets and other devices. A Linux kernel distributed by Allwinner for use on these devices reportedly contained a backdoor. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: A Linux kernel distributed by Allwinner reportedly contained an simple backdoor that could be used to obtain root access. It was believed to have been left in the kernel by mistake by the authors.[1]

Android Overlay Malware.Name: Android Overlay Malware
Android Overlay Malware.Description: Android Overlay Malware is malware that was used in a 2016 campaign targeting European countries. The malware attempted to trick users into providing banking credentials. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: Android Overlay Malware was distributed by sending SMS messages with an embedded link to the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Interface Spoofing
Techniques Used.Use: Android Overlay Malware used view overlay techniques to present credential input UIs to trick users into providing their banking credentials.[1]

Android/Chuli.A.Name: Android/Chuli.A
Android/Chuli.A.Description: Android/Chuli.A is Android malware that was delivered to activist groups via a spearphishing email with an attachment. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A stole call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A stole contact list data stored both on the the phone and the SIM card.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A used SMS to receive command and control messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A stole SMS message content.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A was delivered via a spearphishing message containing a malicious Android application as an attachment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Device Type Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A gathered device data including phone number, OS version, phone model, and SDK version.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A stole geo-location data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Android/Chuli.A used HTTP uploads to a URL as a command and control mechanism.[1]

ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A.Name: ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A
ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A.Description: ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A is Android malware that is unique because it uses encrypted content within a blog site for command and control. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A uses encrypted content within a blog site for part of its command and control. Specifically, the encrypted content contains URLs for other servers to be used for other aspects of command and control.[1]

AndroRAT.Name: AndroRAT
AndroRAT.Description: AndroRAT is malware that allows a third party to control the device and collect information. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: AndroRAT collects call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: AndroRAT collects contact list information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: AndroRAT captures SMS messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: AndroRAT tracks the device location.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: AndroRAT gathers audio from the microphone.[1]

Arp.Name: Arp
Arp.Description: Arp displays information about a system's Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) cache. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Arp can be used to display ARP configuration information on the host.

ASPXSpy.Name: ASPXSpy
ASPXSpy.Description: ASPXSpy is a Web shell. It has been modified by Threat Group-3390 actors to create the ASPXTool version. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: ASPXSpy is a Web shell. The ASPXTool version used by Threat Group-3390 has been deployed to accessible servers running Internet Information Services (IIS).[1]

at.Name: at
at.Description: at is used to schedule tasks on a system to run at a specified date or time. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: at can be used to schedule a task on a system.[1]

AutoIt backdoor.Name: AutoIt backdoor
AutoIt backdoor.Description: AutoIt backdoor is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the MONSOON campaign. The actors frequently used it in weaponized .pps files exploiting CVE-2014-6352. [1] This malware makes use of the legitimate scripting language for Windows GUI automation with the same name.

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: AutoIt backdoor attempts to escalate privileges by bypassing User Access Control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: AutoIt backdoor has sent a C2 response that was base64-encoded.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: AutoIt backdoor is capable of identifying documents on the victim with the following extensions: .doc; .pdf, .csv, .ppt, .docx, .pst, .xls, .xlsx, .pptx, and .jpeg.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: AutoIt backdoor downloads a PowerShell script that decodes to a typical shellcode loader.[1]

Backdoor.Oldrea.Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Backdoor.Oldrea.Description: Backdoor.Oldrea is a backdoor used by Dragonfly. It appears to be custom malware authored by the group or specifically for it. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Some Backdoor.Oldrea samples contain a publicly available Web browser password recovery tool.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: Some Backdoor.Oldrea samples use standard Base64 + bzip2, and some use standard Base64 + reverse XOR + RSA-2048 to decrypt data received from C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects address book information from Outlook.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives. It also searches for ICS-related software files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea contains a cleanup module that removes traces of itself from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea injects itself into explorer.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about the OS and computer name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects information about the Internet adapter configuration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Backdoor.Oldrea collects the current username from the victim.[1]

BACKSPACE.Name: BACKSPACE
BACKSPACE.Description: BACKSPACE is a backdoor used by APT30 that dates back to at least 2005. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Adversaries can direct BACKSPACE to execute from the command-line on infected hosts, or have BACKSPACE create a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: The "ZJ" variant of BACKSPACE allows "ZJ link" infections with Internet access to relay traffic from "ZJ listen" to a command server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: Newer variants of BACKSPACE will encode C2 communications with a custom system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: The "ZR" variant of BACKSPACE will check to see if known host-based firewalls are installed on the infected systems. BACKSPACE will attempt to establish a C2 channel, then will examine open windows to identify a pop-up from the firewall software and will simulate a mouse-click to allow the connection to proceed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Adversaries can direct BACKSPACE to upload files to the C2 Server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE allows adversaries to search for files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE is capable of deleting Registry keys, sub-keys, and values on a victim system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-Stage Channels
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE attempts to avoid detection by checking a first stage command and control server to determine if it should connect to the second stage server, which performs "louder" interactions with the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE may collect information about running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BACKSPACE uses HTTP as a transport to communicate with its command server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: During its initial execution, BACKSPACE extracts operating system information from the infected host.[1]

BADCALL.Name: BADCALL
BADCALL.Description: BADCALL is a Trojan malware variant used by the group Lazarus Group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL uses port 8000 and 443 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL functions as a proxy server between the victim and C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL encrypts C2 traffic using an XOR/ADD cipher and uses a FakeTLS method.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL disables the Windows firewall before binding to a port.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL modifies the firewall Registry key SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SharedAccess\Parameters\FirewallPolicy\StandardProfileGloballyOpenPorts\\List.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL collects the computer name and host name on the compromised system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BADCALL collects the network adapter information.[1]

BADNEWS.Name: BADNEWS
BADNEWS.Description: BADNEWS is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the Patchwork campaign. Its name was given due to its use of RSS feeds, forums, and blogs for command and control. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use:
BADNEWS monitors USB devices and copies files with certain extensions to
a predefined directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS is sometimes signed with an invalid Authenticode certificate in an apparent effort to make it look more legitimate.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS is capable of executing commands via cmd.exe.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS encrypts C2 data with a ROR by 3 and an XOR by 0x23.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS encodes C2 traffic with base64.[1][3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: When it first starts, BADNEWS crawls the victim's local drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Network Shared Drive
Techniques Used.Use: When it first starts, BADNEWS crawls the victim's mapped drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use:
BADNEWS copies files with certain extensions from USB devices to
a predefined directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: After encrypting C2 data, BADNEWS converts it into a hexadecimal representation and then encodes it into base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS copies documents under 15MB found on the victim system to is the user's %temp%\SMB\ folder. It also copies files from USB devices to a predefined directory.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS typically loads its DLL file into a legitimate signed Java or VMware executable.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS has a command to download an .exe and execute it via CreateProcess API. It can also run with ShellExecute.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS identifies files with certain extensions from USB devices, then copies them to a predefined directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: When it first starts, BADNEWS spawns a new thread to log keystrokes.[1][3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS attempts to hide its payloads using legitimate filenames.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS checks for new hard drives on the victim, such as USB devices, by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS has a command to download an .exe and use process hollowing to inject it into a new process.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS installs a registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS is capable of downloading additional files through C2 channels, including a new version of itself.[1][3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS creates a scheduled task to establish by executing a malicious payload every subsequent minute.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS has a command to take a screenshot and send it to the C2 server.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS establishes a backdoor over HTTP.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: BADNEWS can use multiple C2 channels, including RSS feeds, Github, forums, and blogs. BADNEWS also collects C2 information via a dead drop resolver.[1][3][2]

Bandook.Name: Bandook
Bandook.Description: Bandook is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi, which has been available since roughly 2007  [1] [2].

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook has modules that are capable of capturing audio.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook is capable of spawning a Windows command shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook contains keylogging capabilities[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook has been launched by starting iexplore.exe and replacing it with Bandook's payload.[2][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook is capable of taking an image of and uploading the current desktop.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Bandook has modules that are capable of capturing from a victim's webcam.[1]

Bankshot.Name: Bankshot
Bankshot.Description: Bankshot is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first reported by the Department of Homeland Security in December of 2017. In 2018, Lazarus Group used the Bankshot implant in attacks against the Turkish financial sector. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot grabs a user token using WTSQueryUserToken and then creates a process by impersonating a logged-on user.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot gathers domain and account names/information through process monitoring.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot recursively generates a list of files within a directory and sends them back to the control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot uses the command-line interface to execute arbitrary commands.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot encodes commands from the control server using a range of characters and gzip.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot collects files from the local system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot decodes embedded XOR strings.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot creates processes using the Windows API calls: CreateProcessA() and CreateProcessAsUserA().[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot exfiltrates data over its C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot leverages a known zero-day vulnerability in Adobe Flash to execute the implant into the victims’ machines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot searches for files on the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot marks files to be deleted upon the next system reboot and uninstalls and removes itself from the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot delets all artifacts associated with the malware from the infected machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot can terminate a specific process by its process id.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot writes data into the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Pniumj.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot identifies processes and collects the process ids.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot uploads files and secondary payloads to the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot uses HTTP for command and control communication.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot gathers system information, network addresses, disk type, disk free space, and the operation system version.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot modifies the time of a file as specified by the control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Bankshot binds and listens on port 1058.[2]

BBSRAT.Name: BBSRAT
BBSRAT.Description: BBSRAT is malware with remote access tool functionality that has been used in targeted compromises. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT uses HTTP TCP port 80 and HTTPS TCP port 443 for communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT has been seen persisting via COM hijacking through replacement of the COM object for MruPidlList {42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1} or Microsoft WBEM New Event Subsystem {F3130CDB-AA52-4C3A-AB32-85FFC23AF9C1} depending on the system's CPU architecture.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT uses a custom encryption algorithm on data sent back to the C2 server over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: DLL side-loading has been used to execute BBSRAT through a legitimate Citrix executable ssonsvr.exe which is vulnerable to the technique. The Citrix executable was dropped along with BBSRAT by the dropper.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can list file and directory information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can delete files and directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can modify service configurations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can list running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT has been seen loaded into msiexec.exe through process hollowing to hide its execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT has been loaded through DLL side-loading of a legitimate Citrix executable that is set to persist through the registry run key location: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ssonsvr.exe

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can start, stop, or delete services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT uses GET and POST requests over HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to obtain commands and send ZLIB compressed data back to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BBSRAT can query service configuration information.[1]

BISCUIT.Name: BISCUIT
BISCUIT.Description: BISCUIT is a backdoor that has been used by APT1 since as early as 2007. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: BISCUIT malware contains a secondary fallback command and control server that is contacted after the primary command and control server.[1][2]

Bisonal.Name: Bisonal
Bisonal.Description: Bisonal is malware that has been used in attacks against targets in Russia, South Korea, and Japan. It has been observed in the wild since 2014. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal can launch cmd.exe to execute commands on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal uses 443 for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal variants reported on in 2014 and 2015 used a simple XOR cipher for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal decodes strings in the malware using XOR and RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal deletes its dropper and VBS scripts from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal's DLL file and non-malicious decoy file are encrypted with RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal can obtain a list of running processes on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal adds itself to the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal has the capability to download files to execute on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal uses rundll32.exe to execute as part of the Registry Run key it adds: HKEY_CURRENT_USER \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\”vert” = “rundll32.exe c:\windows\temp\pvcu.dll , Qszdez”.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal's dropper creates VBS scripts on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal uses HTTP for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Bisonal samples encrypt C2 communications with RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal has a command to gather system information from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Bisonal can execute ipconfig on the victim’s machine.[1]

BITSAdmin.Name: BITSAdmin
BITSAdmin.Description: BITSAdmin is a command line tool used to create and manage BITS Jobs. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BITSAdmin can be used to create BITS Jobs to upload files from a compromised host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: BITSAdmin can be used to create BITS Jobs to upload and/or download files.[1]

BLACKCOFFEE.Name: BLACKCOFFEE
BLACKCOFFEE.Description: BLACKCOFFEE is malware that has been used by several Chinese groups since at least 2013. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to create a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to enumerate files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to delete files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-Stage Channels
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain an encoded tag containing the IP address of a command and control server and then communicates separately with that IP address for C2. If the C2 server is discovered or shut down, the threat actors can update the encoded IP address on TechNet to maintain control of the victims’ machines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE has the capability to discover processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: BLACKCOFFEE uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server. It has also obfuscated its C2 traffic as normal traffic to sites such as Github.[1][2]

BlackEnergy.Name: BlackEnergy
BlackEnergy.Description: BlackEnergy is a malware toolkit that has been used by both criminal and APT actors. It dates back to at least 2007 and was originally designed to create botnets for use in conducting Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, but its use has evolved to support various plug-ins. It is well known for being used during the confrontation between Georgia and Russia in 2008, as well as in targeting Ukrainian institutions. Variants include BlackEnergy 2 and BlackEnergy 3. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy attempts to bypass default User Access Control (UAC) settings by exploiting a backward-compatibility setting found in Windows 7 and later.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat! email client, Mozilla password manager, Google Chrome password manager, Outlook, Internet Explorer, and Windows Credential Store.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has the capability to communicate over a backup channel via plus.google.com.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy gathers a list of installed apps from the uninstall program Registry. It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry. BlackEnergy has searched for given file types.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy 2 contains a "Destroy" plug-in that destroys data stored on victim hard drives by overwriting file contents.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File System Permissions Weakness
Techniques Used.Use: One variant of BlackEnergy locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable. The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: The BlackEnergy component KillDisk is capable of deleting Windows Event Logs.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has run a keylogger plug-in on a victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has conducted port scans on a host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: One variant of BlackEnergy creates a new service using either a hard-coded or randomly generated name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy can gather very specific information about attached USB devices, to include device instance ID and drive geometry.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has gathered a process list by using Tasklist.exe.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: The BlackEnergy 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy is capable of taking screenshots.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: The BlackEnergy 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has used Systeminfo to gather the OS version, as well as information on the system configuration, BIOS, the motherboard, and the processor.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has gathered information about network IP configurations using ipconfig.exe and about routing tables using route.exe.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has gathered information about local network connections using netstat.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: BlackEnergy has run a plug-in on a victim to spread through the local network by using PsExec and accessing admin shares.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: A BlackEnergy 2 plug-in uses WMI to gather victim host details.[3]

BOOTRASH.Name: BOOTRASH
BOOTRASH.Description: BOOTRASH is a Bootkit that targets Windows operating systems. It has been used by threat actors that target the financial sector. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bootkit
Techniques Used.Use: BOOTRASH is a Volume Boot Record (VBR) bootkit that uses the VBR to maintain persistence.[1]

BrainTest.Name: BrainTest
BrainTest.Description: BrainTest is a family of Android malware. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: Original samples of BrainTest download their exploit packs for rooting from a remote server after installation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: Some original variants of BrainTest had the capability to automatically root some devices, but that behavior was not observed in later samples.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Manipulate App Store Rankings or Ratings
Techniques Used.Use: BrainTest provided capabilities that allowed developers to use compromised devices to post positive reviews on their own malicious applications as well as download other malicious applications they had submitted to the Play Store.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify System Partition
Techniques Used.Use: BrainTest uses root privileges (if available) to copy an additional Android app package (APK) to /system/priv-app to maintain persistence even after a factory reset.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: BrainTest stores a secondary Android app package (APK) in its assets directory in encrypted form, and decrypts the payload at runtime.[2]

Brave Prince.Name: Brave Prince
Brave Prince.Description: Brave Prince is a Korean-language implant that was first observed in the wild in December 2017. It contains similar code and behavior to Gold Dragon, and was seen along with Gold Dragon and RunningRAT in operations surrounding the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince terminates antimalware processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince gathers file and directory information from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince lists the running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince gathers information about the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Brave Prince variants have used South Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince collects hard drive content and system configuration information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Brave Prince gathers network configuration information as well as the ARP cache.[1]

Briba.Name: Briba
Briba.Description: Briba is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor and download files on to compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Briba connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Briba installs a service pointing to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Briba creates run key Registry entries pointing to malicious DLLs dropped to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Briba downloads files onto infected hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Briba uses rundll32 within Registry Run Keys / Start Folder entries to execute malicious DLLs.[2]

BS2005.Name: BS2005
BS2005.Description: BS2005 is malware that was used by Ke3chang in spearphishing campaigns since at least 2011. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: BS2005 uses Base64 encoding for communication in the message body of an HTTP request.[1]

BUBBLEWRAP.Name: BUBBLEWRAP
BUBBLEWRAP.Description: BUBBLEWRAP is a full-featured, second-stage backdoor used by the admin@338 group. It is set to run when the system boots and includes functionality to check, upload, and register plug-ins that can further enhance its capabilities. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BUBBLEWRAP can communicate using HTTP or HTTPS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BUBBLEWRAP can communicate using SOCKS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BUBBLEWRAP collects system information, including the operating system version and hostname.[1]

Cachedump.Name: Cachedump
Cachedump.Description: Cachedump is a publicly-available tool that program extracts cached password hashes from a system’s registry. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Cachedump can extract cached password hashes from a system’s registry.[1]

CALENDAR.Name: CALENDAR
CALENDAR.Description: CALENDAR is malware used by APT1 that mimics legitimate Gmail Calendar traffic. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: The CALENDAR malware communicates through the use of events in Google Calendar.[1][2]

Calisto.Name: Calisto
Calisto.Description: Calisto is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. Calisto is believed to have first been developed in 2016. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto adds permissions and remote logins to all users.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto collects information on bookmarks from Google Chrome.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto attempted to contact the C2 server over TCP using port 80.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto has the capability to add its own account to the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto uses the zip -r command to compress the data collected on the local system.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto can collect data from user directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto has the capability to use rm -rf to remove folders and files from the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Prompt
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto presents an input prompt asking for the user's login and password.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Keychain
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto collects Keychain storage data and copies those passwords/tokens to a file.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto adds a .plist file to the /Library/LaunchAgents folder to maintain persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Launchctl
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto uses launchctl to enable screen sharing on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto's installation file is an unsigned DMG image under the guise of Intego’s security solution for mac.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto has the capability to upload and download files to the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Calisto runs the ifconfig command to obtain the IP address from the victim’s machine.[1]

CallMe.Name: CallMe
CallMe.Description: CallMe is a Trojan designed to run on Apple OSX. It is based on a publicly available tool called Tiny SHell. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: CallMe has the capability to create a reverse shell on victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: CallMe exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: CallMe has the capability to download a file to the victim from the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CallMe uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.[1]

Carbanak.Name: Carbanak
Carbanak.Description: Carbanak is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name (Carbanak). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak has a command to create a reverse shell.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak uses Port Numbers 443 and 80 for the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak can create a Windows account.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak obtains Windows logon password details.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak uses a custom binary protocol for C2 communications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak uses XOR with random keys for its communications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak searches recursively for Outlook personal storage tables (PST) files within user directories and sends them back to the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak has a command to delete files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak logs key strokes for configured processes and sends them back to the C2 server.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak lists running processes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak downloads an executable and injects it directly into a new process.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak checks the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings for proxy configurations information.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak stores a configuration files in the startup directory to automatically execute commands in order to persist across reboots.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Access Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak has a plugin for VNC and Ammyy Admin Tool.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak enables concurrent Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak performs desktop video recording and captures screenshots of the desktop and sends it to the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Carbanak malware communicates to its command server using HTTP with an encrypted payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak encrypts the message body of HTTP traffic with RC2 (in CBC mode) and Base64 encoding.[1][2]

Catchamas.Name: Catchamas
Catchamas.Description: Catchamas is a Windows Trojan that steals information from compromised systems. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas obtains application windows titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas steals data stored in the clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas stores the gathered data from the machine in .db files and .bmp files under four separate locations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas collects keystrokes from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas adds a new service named NetAdapter in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas creates three Registry keys to establish persistence by adding a New Service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas adds a new service named NetAdapter to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas captures screenshots based on specific keywords in the window’s title.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Catchamas gathers the Mac address, IP address, and the network adapter information from the victim’s machine.[1]

CCBkdr.Name: CCBkdr
CCBkdr.Description: CCBkdr is malware that was injected into a signed version of CCleaner and distributed from CCleaner's distribution website. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: CCBkdr was added to a legitimate, signed version 5.33 of the CCleaner software and distributed on CCleaner's distribution site.[1][2][3]

certutil.Name: certutil
certutil.Description: certutil is a command-line utility that can be used to obtain certificate authority information and configure Certificate Services. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: certutil has been used to decode binaries hidden inside certificate files as Base64 information.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Install Root Certificate
Techniques Used.Use: certutil can be used to install browser root certificates as a precursor to performing man-in-the-middle between connections to banking websites. Example command: certutil -addstore -f -user ROOT ProgramData\cert512121.der.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: certutil can be used to download files from a given URL.[1][4]

Chaos.Name: Chaos
Chaos.Description: Chaos is Linux malware that compromises systems by brute force attacks against SSH services. Once installed, it provides a reverse shell to its controllers, triggered by unsolicited packets. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Chaos conducts brute force attacks against SSH services to gain initial access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Chaos provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Chaos provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-Stage Channels
Techniques Used.Use: After initial compromise, Chaos will download a second stage to establish a more permanent presence on the affected system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Port Knocking
Techniques Used.Use: Chaos provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Chaos provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.[1]

Charger.Name: Charger
Charger.Description: Charger is Android malware that steals steals contacts and SMS messages from the user's device. It can also lock the device and demand ransom payment if it receives admin permissions. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Charger steals contacts from the victim user's device.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Charger checks the local settings of the device and does not run its malicious logic if the device is located in Ukraine, Russia, or Belarus.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Lock User Out of Device
Techniques Used.Use: Charger locks the device if it is granted admin permissions, displaying a message demanding a "ransom" payment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: Charger encodes strings into binary arrays to make it difficult to inspect them. It also loads code from encrypted resources dynamically and includes meaningless commands that mask the actual commands passing through.[1]

ChChes.Name: ChChes
ChChes.Description: ChChes is a Trojan that appears to be used exclusively by menuPass. It was used to target Japanese organizations in 2016. Its lack of persistence methods suggests it may be intended as a first-stage tool. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes samples were digitally signed with a certificate originally used by Hacking Team that was later leaked and subsequently revoked.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes steals credentials stored inside Internet Explorer.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes can encrypt C2 data with a custom technique using MD5, base64-encoding, and RC4.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes can alter the victim's proxy configuration.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes collects the victim's %TEMP% directory path and version of Internet Explorer.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes copies itself to an .exe file with a filename that is likely intended to imitate Norton Antivirus but has several letters reversed (e.g. notron.exe).[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes collects its process identifier (PID) on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes establishes persistence by adding a Registry Run key.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes is capable of downloading files, including additional modules.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes communicates to its C2 server over HTTP and embeds data within the Cookie HTTP header.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes can encrypt C2 traffic with AES.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ChChes collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.[1][3]

Cherry Picker.Name: Cherry Picker
Cherry Picker.Description: Cherry Picker is a point of sale (PoS) memory scraper. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: AppInit DLLs
Techniques Used.Use: Some variants of Cherry Picker use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll"[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cherry Picker exfiltrates files over FTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Recent versions of Cherry Picker delete files and registry keys created by the malware.[1]

China Chopper.Name: China Chopper
China Chopper.Description: China Chopper is a Web Shell hosted on Web servers to provide access back into an enterprise network that does not rely on an infected system calling back to a remote command and control server. [1] It has been used by several threat groups. [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: China Chopper is capable of opening a command terminal.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: China Chopper can list directory contents.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: China Chopper can upload and download files.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: China Chopper executes code using HTTP POST commands.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: The China Chopper backdoor is a Web shell that supports server payloads for many different kinds of server-side scripting languages and contains functionality to access files, connect to a database, and open a virtual command prompt.[1]

CHOPSTICK.Name: CHOPSTICK
CHOPSTICK.Description: CHOPSTICK is a malware family of modular backdoors used by APT28. It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. [1] [2] [3] [4] It is tracked separately from the Android version of the malware.

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK is capable of performing remote command execution.[5][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Communication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines, using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.[1][2][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK can switch to a new C2 channel if the current one is broken.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: An older version of CHOPSTICK has a module that monitors all mounted volumes for files with the extensions .doc, .docx, .pgp, .gpg, .m2f, or .m2o.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK is capable of performing keylogging.[5][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK may store RC4 encrypted configuration information in the Windows Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK is capable of performing remote file transmission.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.[1][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK has the capability to capture screenshots.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK checks for anti-virus, forensics, and virtualization software.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Various implementations of CHOPSTICK communicate with C2 over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CHOPSTICK encrypts C2 communications with RC4 as well as TLS.[2]

CloudDuke.Name: CloudDuke
CloudDuke.Description: CloudDuke is malware that was used by APT29 in 2015. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: CloudDuke downloads and executes additional malware from either a Web address or a Microsoft OneDrive account.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: One variant of CloudDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: One variant of CloudDuke uses a Microsoft OneDrive account to exchange commands and stolen data with its operators.[1]

cmd.Name: cmd
cmd.Description:
cmd is the Windows command-line interpreter that can be used to interact with systems and execute other processes and utilities. [1]
Cmd.exe contains native functionality to perform many operations to interact with the system, including listing files in a directory (e.g., dir [2]), deleting files (e.g., del [3]), and copying files (e.g., copy [4]).

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: cmd is used to execute programs and other actions at the command-line interface.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: cmd can be used to find files and directories with native functionality such as dir commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: cmd can be used to delete files from the file system.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: cmd can be used to copy files to a remotely connected system.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: cmd can be used to find information about the operating system.[2]

Cobalt Strike.Name: Cobalt Strike
Cobalt Strike.Description:
Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured, penetration testing tool which bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system. [1]
In addition to its own capabilities, Cobalt Strike leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and Mimikatz. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can steal access tokens from exiting processes and make tokens from known credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: BITS Jobs
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can download a hosted "beacon" payload using BITSAdmin.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use a number of known techniques to bypass Windows UAC.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike uses a command-line interface to interact with systems.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports. The C2 protocol is encapsulated in common application layer protocols.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts. This can be used to limit the number of egress points, or provide access to a host without direct internet access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can recover hashed passwords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike allows adversaries to modify the way the "beacon" payload communicates. This is called "Malleable C2" in the Cobalt Strike manual and is intended to allow a penetration test team to mimic known APT C2 methods.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can collect data from a local system.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Distributed Component Object Model
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can deliver "beacon" payloads for lateral movement by leveraging remote COM execution.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload is capable of running shell commands without cmd.exe and PowerShell commands without powershell.exe[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can exploit vulnerabilities such as MS14-058.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike includes a capability to modify the "beacon" payload to eliminate known signatures or unpacking methods.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can track key presses with a keylogger module.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Man in the Browser
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can perform browser pivoting and inject into a user's browser to inherit cookies, authenticated HTTP sessions, and client SSL certificates.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multiband Communication
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload can receive C2 from one protocol and respond on another. This is typically a mixture of HTTP, HTTPS, and DNS traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can perform port scans from an infected host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can query shared drives on the local system.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can install a new service.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can perform pass the hash.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can execute a payload on a remote host with PowerShell. This technique does write any data to disk.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload can collect information on process details.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use process hollowing for execution.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can inject a variety of payloads into processes dynamically chosen by the adversary.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can start a VNC-based remote desktop server and tunnel the connection through the already established C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can SSH to a remote service.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike uses the native Windows Network Enumeration APIs to interrogate and discover targets in a Windows Active Directory network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can set its "beacon" payload to reach out to the C2 server on an arbitrary and random interval. In addition it will break large data sets into smaller chunks for exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike's "beacon" payload is capable of capturing screen shots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use PowerSploit or other scripting frameworks to perform execution.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use PsExec to execute a payload on a remote host. It can also use Service Control Manager to start new services.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike uses a custom command and control protocol that is encapsulated in HTTP, HTTPS, or DNS. In addition, it conducts peer-to-peer communication over Windows named pipes encapsulated in the SMB protocol. All protocols use their standard assigned ports.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike will timestomp any files or payloads placed on a target machine to help them blend in.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as another user.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use Window admin shares (C$ and ADMIN$) for lateral movement.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use WMI to deliver a payload to a remote host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Remote Management
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Strike can use WinRM to execute a payload on a remote host.[1]

Comnie.Name: Comnie
Comnie.Description: Comnie is a remote backdoor which has been used in attacks in East Asia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses the net user command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie executes a batch script to store discovery information in %TEMP%\info.dat and then uploads the temporarily file to the remote C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie appends a total of 64MB of garbage data to a file to deter any security products in place that may be scanning files on disk.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses Port Numbers 80, 8080, 8000, and 443 for communication to the C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses the tasklist to view running processes on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie achieves persistence by adding a shortcut of itself to the startup path in the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie runs the net view command

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses Rundll32 to load a malicious DLL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie executes BAT and VBS scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie attempts to detect several anti-virus products.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie establishes persistence via a .lnk file in the victim’s startup path.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses HTTP for C2 communication.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie encrypts command and control communications with RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie collects the hostname of the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses ipconfig /all and route PRINT to identify network adapter and interface information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie executes the netstat -ano command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie runs the command: net start >> %TEMP%\info.dat on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Comnie uses blogs and third-party sites (GitHub, tumbler, and BlogSpot) to avoid DNS-based blocking of their communication to the command and control server.[1]

ComRAT.Name: ComRAT
ComRAT.Description: ComRAT is a remote access tool suspected of being a decedent of Agent.btz and used by Turla. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: ComRAT samples have been seen which hijack COM objects for persistence by replacing the path to shell32.dll in registry location HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ComRAT has used HTTP requests for command and control.[2]

CORALDECK.Name: CORALDECK
CORALDECK.Description: CORALDECK is an exfiltration tool used by ScarCruft. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: CORALDECK has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: CORALDECK has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: CORALDECK searches for specified files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CORALDECK has exfiltrated data in HTTP POST headers.[1]

CORESHELL.Name: CORESHELL
CORESHELL.Description: CORESHELL is a downloader used by APT28. The older versions of this malware are known as SOURFACE and newer versions as CORESHELL. It has also been referred to as Sofacy, though that term has been used widely to refer to both the group APT28 and malware families associated with the group. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL contains unused machine instructions in a likely attempt to hinder analysis.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL C2 messages are Base64-encoded.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL has established persistence by creating autostart extensibility point (ASEP) Registry entries in the Run key and other Registry keys, as well as by creating shortcuts in the Internet Explorer Quick Start folder.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL downloads another dropper from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL is installed via execution of rundll32 with an export named "init" or "InitW."[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL can communicate over HTTP, SMTP, and POP3 for C2.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: CORESHELL collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.[1]

CosmicDuke.Name: CosmicDuke
CosmicDuke.Description: CosmicDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Exfiltration
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke exfiltrates collected files automatically over FTP to remote servers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke copies and exfiltrates the clipboard contents every 30 seconds.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs and browsers, including popular instant messaging applications, Web browsers, and email clients. Windows account hashes, domain accounts, and LSA secrets are also collected, as are WLAN keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke contains a custom version of the RC4 algorithm that includes a programming error.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke steals user files from local hard drives with file extensions that match a predefined list.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Network Shared Drive
