Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke steals user files from network shared drives with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke steals user files from removable media with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke searches for Microsoft Outlook data files with extensions .pst and .ost for collection and exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke exfiltrates collected files over FTP or WebDAV. Exfiltration servers can be separately configured from C2 servers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke attempts to exploit privilege escalation vulnerabilities CVE-2010-0232 or CVE-2010-4398.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke searches attached and mounted drives for file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke uses a keylogger and steals clipboard contents from victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke uses Windows services typically named "javamtsup" for persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke uses scheduled tasks typically named "Watchmon Service" for persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke takes periodic screenshots and exfiltrates them.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CosmicDuke can use HTTP or HTTPS for command and control to hard-coded C2 servers.[1][2]

CozyCar.Name: CozyCar
CozyCar.Description: CozyCar is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015. It is a modular malware platform, and its backdoor component can be instructed to download and execute a variety of modules with different functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: A module in CozyCar allows arbitrary commands to be executed by invoking C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Password stealer and NTLM stealer modules in CozyCar harvest stored credentials from the victim, including credentials used as part of Windows NTLM user authentication. CozyCar has also executed Mimikatz for further victim penetration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: The CozyCar dropper has masqueraded a copy of the infected system's rundll32.exe executable that was moved to the malware's install directory and renamed according to a predefined configuration file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to register itself as a Windows service.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: The payload of CozyCar is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key. The CozyCar configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to set itself to be executed at system startup by adding a Registry value under one of the following Registry keys: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: The CozyCar dropper copies the system file rundll32.exe to the install location for the malware, then uses the copy of rundll32.exe to load and execute the main CozyCar component.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: One persistence mechanism used by CozyCar is to register itself as a scheduled task.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The main CozyCar dropper checks whether the victim has an anti-virus product installed. If the installed product is on a predetermined list, the dropper will exit. Newer versions of CozyCar will check to ensure it is not being executed inside a virtual machine or a known malware analysis sandbox environment. If it detects that it is, it will exit.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: CozyCar's main method of communicating with its C2 servers is using HTTP or HTTPS.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A system info module in CozyCar gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: CozyCar uses Twitter as a backup C2 channel to Twitter accounts specified in its configuration file.[2]

Crimson.Name: Crimson
Crimson.Description: Crimson is malware used as part of a campaign known as Operation Transparent Tribe that targeted Indian diplomatic and military victims. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a module to steal credentials from Web browsers on the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a module to collect data from removable drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to collect and exfiltrate emails from Outlook.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains commands to list files and directories, as well as search for files matching certain extensions from a defined list.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to list processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to retrieve files from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to perform screen captures.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to collect information about anti-virus software on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to collect the victim PC name and operating system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Crimson contains a command to collect the victim MAC address and LAN IP.[1]

CrossRAT.Name: CrossRAT
CrossRAT.Description: CrossRAT is a cross platform RAT.

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: CrossRAT can list all files on a system.

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: CrossRAT creates a Launch Agent on macOS.

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: CrossRAT uses run keys for persistence on Windows

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: CrossRAT is capable of taking screen captures.

Daserf.Name: Daserf
Daserf.Description: Daserf is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Some Daserf samples were signed with a stolen digital certificate.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf can execute shell commands.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf leverages Mimikatz and Windows Credential Editor to steal credentials.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf uses custom base64 encoding to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Analysis of Daserf has shown that it regularly undergoes technical improvements to evade anti-virus detection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf can log keystrokes.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf uses file and folder names related to legitimate programs in order to blend in, such as HP, Intel, Adobe, and perflogs.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf can download remote files.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf can take screenshots.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: A version of Daserf uses the MPRESS packer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf uses HTTP for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Daserf uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[2]

DDKONG.Name: DDKONG
DDKONG.Description: DDKONG is a malware sample that was part of a campaign by Rancor. DDKONG was first seen used in February 2017. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: DDKONG communicates over raw TCP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: DDKONG decodes an embedded configuration using XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DDKONG lists files on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: DDKONG downloads and uploads files on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: DDKONG uses Rundll32 to ensure only a single instance of itself is running at once.[1]

DealersChoice.Name: DealersChoice
DealersChoice.Description: DealersChoice is a Flash exploitation framework used by APT28. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: DealersChoice leverages vulnerable versions of Flash to perform execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: DealersChoice makes modifications to open-source scripts from GitHub and executes them on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: DealersChoice uses HTTP for communication with the C2 server.[1]

Dendroid.Name: Dendroid
Dendroid.Description: Dendroid is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Dendroid can take pictures using the phone’s camera as well as record audio and video.[1]

Derusbi.Name: Derusbi
Derusbi.Description: Derusbi is malware used by multiple Chinese APT groups. [1] [2] Both Windows and Linux variants have been observed. [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of performing audio captures.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of creating a remote Bash shell and executing commands.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi beacons to destination port 443.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi obfuscates C2 traffic with variable 4-byte XOR keys.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi uses a backup communication method with an HTTP beacon.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of obtaining directory, file, and drive listings.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of deleting files. It has been observed loading a Linux Kernel Module (LKM) and then deleting it from the hard disk as well as overwriting the data with null bytes.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of logging keystrokes.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi collects current and parent process IDs.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi injects itself into the secure shell (SSH) process.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi variants have been seen that use Registry persistence to proxy execution through regsvr32.exe.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of performing screen captures.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A Linux version of Derusbi checks if the victim user ID is anything other than zero (normally used for root), and the malware will not execute if it does not have root privileges. Derusbi also gathers the username of the victim.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: The Derusbi malware supports timestomping.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Derusbi is capable of capturing video.[4]

Dipsind.Name: Dipsind
Dipsind.Description: Dipsind is a malware family of backdoors that appear to be used exclusively by PLATINUM. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind can spawn remote shells.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: A Dipsind variant uses a C2 mechanism similar to port knocking that allows attackers to connect to a victim without leaving the connection open for more than a few sectonds.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind encodes C2 traffic with base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind can download remote files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind can be configured to only run during normal working hours, which would make its communications harder to distinguish from normal traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dipsind encrypts C2 data with AES256 in ECB mode.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Techniques Used.Use: A Dipsind variant registers as a Winlogon Event Notify DLL to establish persistence.[1]

DOGCALL.Name: DOGCALL
DOGCALL.Description: DOGCALL is a backdoor used by ScarCruft that has been used to target South Korean government and military organizations in 2017. It is typically dropped using a Hangul Word Processor (HWP) exploit. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: DOGCALL is capable of logging keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: DOGCALL is capable of capturing screenshots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: DOGCALL is capable of leveraging cloud storage APIs such as Cloud, Box, Dropbox, and Yandex for C2.[1]

Dok.Name: Dok
Dok.Description: Dok steals banking information through man-in-the-middle  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: AppleScript
Techniques Used.Use: Dok uses AppleScript to create a login item for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Prompt
Techniques Used.Use: Dok prompts the user for credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Install Root Certificate
Techniques Used.Use: Dok installs a root certificate to aid in man-in-the-middle actions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: Dok persists via a Launch Agent.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Login Item
Techniques Used.Use: Dok persists via a login item.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-hop Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Dok downloads and installs Tor via homebrew.[1]

Downdelph.Name: Downdelph
Downdelph.Description: Downdelph is a first-stage downloader written in Delphi that has been used by APT28 in rare instances between 2013 and 2015. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Downdelph bypasses UAC to escalate privileges by using a custom “RedirectEXE” shim database.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: Downdelph inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Downdelph uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: After downloading its main config file, Downdelph downloads multiple payloads from C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Downdelph uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.[1]

DownPaper.Name: DownPaper
DownPaper.Description: DownPaper is a backdoor Trojan; its main functionality is to download and run second stage malware. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper uses the command line.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper uses PowerShell for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper searches and reads the value of the Windows Update Registry Run key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper uses PowerShell to add a Registry Run key in order to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper communicates to its C2 server over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper collects the victim host name and serial number, and then sends the information to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DownPaper collects the victim username and sends it to the C2 server.[1]

DressCode.Name: DressCode
DressCode.Description: DressCode is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit Enterprise Resources
Techniques Used.Use: DressCode sets up a "general purpose tunnel" that can be used by an adversary to compromise enterprise networks that the mobile device is connected to.[1]

DroidJack.Name: DroidJack
DroidJack.Description: DroidJack RAT is an Android remote access tool that has been observed posing as legitimate applications including the Super Mario Run and Pokemon GO games. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: DroidJack RAT captures call data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: DroidJack RAT captures SMS data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: DroidJack RAT performs call recording and video capturing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Repackaged Application
Techniques Used.Use: DroidJack RAT included code from the legitimate Pokemon GO app in order to appear identical to the user, but it also included additional malicious code.[2]

dsquery.Name: dsquery
dsquery.Description: dsquery is a command-line utility that can be used to query Active Directory for information from a system within a domain. [1] It is typically installed only on Windows Server versions but can be installed on non-server variants through the Microsoft-provided Remote Server Administration Tools bundle.

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: dsquery can be used to gather information on user accounts within a domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: dsquery can be used to gather information on permission groups within a domain.[1]

DualToy.Name: DualToy
DualToy.Description: DualToy is Windows malware that installs malicious applications onto Android and iOS devices connected over USB. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit via Charging Station or PC
Techniques Used.Use: DualToy side loads malicious or risky apps to both Android and iOS devices via a USB connection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DualToy collects the connected iOS device’s information including IMEI, IMSI, ICCID, serial number and phone number.[1]

Duqu.Name: Duqu
Duqu.Description: Duqu is a malware platform that uses a modular approach to extend functionality after deployment within a target network. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu examines running system processes for tokens that have specific system privileges. If it finds one, it will copy the token and store it for later use. Eventually it will start new processes with the stored token attached. It can also steal tokens to acquire administrative privileges.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on accounts and permissions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on open windows.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts if some of the hosts do not have Internet access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu is capable of using its command and control protocol over port 443. However, Duqu is also capable of encapsulating its command protocol over standard application layer protocols. The Duqu command and control protocol implements many of the same features as TCP and is a reliable transport protocol.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: When the Duqu command and control is operating over HTTP or HTTPS, Duqu uploads data to its controller by appending it to a blank JPG file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Modules can be pushed to and executed by Duqu that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu can track key presses with a keylogger module.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu creates a new service that loads a malicious driver when the system starts. When Duqu is active, the operating system believes that the driver is legitimate, as it has been signed with a valid private key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on process details.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu is capable of loading executable code via process hollowing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu will inject itself into different processes to evade detection. The selection of the target process is influenced by the security software that is installed on the system (Duqu will inject into different processes depending on which security suite is installed on the infected host).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Duqu uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Duqu command and control protocol's data stream can be encrypted with AES-CBC.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The reconnaissance modules used with Duqu can collect information on network configuration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The discovery modules used with Duqu can collect information on network connections.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.[1]

DustySky.Name: DustySky
DustySky.Description: DustySky is multi-stage malware written in .NET that has been used by Molerats since May 2015. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky has two hard-coded domains for C2 servers; if the first does not respond, it will try the second.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky scans the victim for files that contain certain keywords from a list that is obtained from the C2 as a text file. It also collects information about installed software.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky contains a keylogger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: The DustySky dropper uses a function to obfuscate the name of functions and other parts of the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky collects information about running processes from victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky achieves persistence by creating a Registry entry in HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky searches for network drives and removable media and duplicates itself onto them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky checks for the existence of anti-virus.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky has used both HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: DustySky extracts basic information about the operating system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: The DustySky dropper uses Windows Management Instrumentation to extract information about the operating system and whether an anti-virus is active.[1]

Dyre.Name: Dyre
Dyre.Description:
Dyre is a Trojan that has been used for financial gain. 
 [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Dyre decrypts resources needed for targeting the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Dyre registers itself as a service by adding several Registry keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Dyre injects into other processes to load modules.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Dyre has a command to download and executes additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The Dyre crimeware toolkit has refined its detection of sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dyre uses HTTPS for C2 communications.[1]

Elise.Name: Elise
Elise.Description:
Elise is a custom backdoor Trojan that appears to be used exclusively by Lotus Blossom. It is part of a larger group of
tools referred to as LStudio, ST Group, and APT0LSTU. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Elise executes net user after initial communication is made to the remote server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Elise exfiltrates data using cookie values that are Base64-encoded.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A variant of Elise executes dir C:\progra~1 when initially run.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: If installing itself as a service fails, Elise instead writes itself as a file named svchost.exe saved in %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Elise configures itself as a service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Elise encrypts several of its files, including configuration files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Elise injects DLL files into iexplore.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: If establishing persistence by installation as a new service fails, one variant of Elise establishes persistence for the created .exe file by setting the following Registry key: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\svchost : %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network\svchost.exe. Other variants have set the following Registry key for persistence: HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\imejp : [self].[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: After copying itself to a DLL file, a variant of Elise calls the DLL file using rundll32.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Elise communicates over HTTP or HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Elise encrypts exfiltrated data with RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Elise executes systeminfo after initial communication is made to the remote server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Elise executes ipconfig /all after initial communication is made to the remote server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Elise executes net start after initial communication is made to the remote server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Elise performs timestomping of a CAB file it creates.[1]

ELMER.Name: ELMER
ELMER.Description: ELMER is a non-persistent, proxy-aware HTTP backdoor written in Delphi that has been used by APT16. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: ELMER uses HTTP over port 443 for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ELMER is capable of performing directory listings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ELMER is capable of performing process listings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ELMER uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

Emissary.Name: Emissary
Emissary.Description: Emissary is a Trojan that has been used by Lotus Blossom. It shares code with Elise, with both Trojans being part of a malware group referred to as LStudio. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: A variant of Emissary appends junk data to the end of its DLL file to create a large file that may exceed the maximum size that anti-virus programs can scan.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to create a remote shell and execute specified commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of Emissary contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications. Some variants of Emissary use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary is capable of configuring itself as a service.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Variants of Emissary encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to execute the command net localgroup administrators.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Variants of Emissary have added Run Registry keys to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to download files from the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Variants of Emissary have used rundll32.exe in Registry values added to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary uses HTTP or HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to execute ver, systeminfo, and gpresult commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to execute the command ipconfig /all.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Emissary has the capability to execute the command net start to interact with services.[2]

Epic.Name: Epic
Epic.Description: Epic is a backdoor that has been used by Turla. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used valid digital certificates from Sysprint AG to sign its Epic dropper.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Epic implements a command and control protocol over HTTP.[1]

EvilGrab.Name: EvilGrab
EvilGrab.Description: EvilGrab is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by menuPass via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab has the capability to capture audio from a victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab uses port 8080 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab has the capability to capture keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab adds a Registry Run key for ctfmon.exe to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab has the capability to capture screenshots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: EvilGrab has the capability to capture video from a victim machine.[1]

FakeM.Name: FakeM
FakeM.Description: FakeM is a shellcode-based Windows backdoor that has been used by Scarlet Mimic. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The original variant of FakeM encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of “YHCRA” and bit rotation between each XOR operation. FakeM has also included HTML code in C2 traffic in an apparent attempt to evade detection. Additionally, some variants of FakeM use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: FakeM C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: FakeM contains a keylogger module.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some variants of FakeM use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some variants of FakeM use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[1]

FALLCHILL.Name: FALLCHILL
FALLCHILL.Description: FALLCHILL is a RAT that has been used by Lazarus Group since at least 2016 to target the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance industries. It is usually dropped by other Lazarus Group malware or delivered when a victim unknowingly visits a compromised website. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server, encoding data with RC4 encryption.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL can search files on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL can delete malware and associated artifacts from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL collects MAC address and local IP address information from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: FALLCHILL can modify file or directory timestamps.[1]

Felismus.Name: Felismus
Felismus.Description: Felismus is a modular backdoor that has been used by Sowbug. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus uses command line for execution.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Felismus samples use a custom encryption method for C2 traffic using AES, base64 encoding, and multiple keys.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus has masqueraded as legitimate Adobe Content Management System files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus can download files from remote servers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus checks for processes associated with anti-virus vendors.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus uses HTTP for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Felismus samples use AES to encrypt C2 traffic.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus collects the system information, including hostname and OS version, and sends it to the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus collects the victim LAN IP address and sends it to the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Felismus collects the current username and sends it to the C2 server.[2]

FELIXROOT.Name: FELIXROOT
FELIXROOT.Description: FELIXROOT is a backdoor that has been used to target Ukrainian victims. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT opens a remote shell to execute commands on the infected system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT uses port 443 for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT deletes the .LNK file from the startup directory as well as the dropper components.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT deletes the Registry key HKCU\Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32.exe\shell\open.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT downloads and uploads files to and from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT uses Rundll32 for executing the dropper program.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT executes batch scripts on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT uses HTTP and HTTPS to communicate with the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, and volume serial number.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FELIXROOT collects the username from the victim’s machine.[1]

Fgdump.Name: Fgdump
Fgdump.Description: Fgdump is a Windows password hash dumper. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Fgdump can dump Windows password hashes.[1]

FinFisher.Name: FinFisher
FinFisher.Description: FinFisher is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including Wingbird. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher uses token manipulation with NtFilterToken as part of UAC bypass.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher contains junk code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Bootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Some FinFisher variants incorporate an MBR rootkit.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher performs UAC bypass.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher extracts and decrypts stage 3 malware, which is stored in encrypted resources.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: A FinFisher variant uses DLL search order hijacking.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher uses DLL side-loading to load malicious programs.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher enumerates directories and scans for certain files.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Hooking
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher hooks processes by modifying IAT pointers to CreateWindowEx.[1][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher clears the system event logs.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher renames one of its .dll files to uxtheme.dll in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate file.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher creates a new Windows service with the malicious executable for persistence.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher is heavily obfuscated in many ways, including through the use of spaghetti code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs. It also uses a custom XOR algorithm to obfuscate code.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher checks its parent process for indications that it is running in a sandbox setup.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher injects itself into various processes depending on whether it is low integrity or high integrity.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher queries Registry values as part of its anti-sandbox checks.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher establishes persistence by creating the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Run.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher takes a screenshot of the screen and displays it on top of all other windows for few seconds in an apparent attempt to hide some messages showed by the system during the setup process.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher probes the system to check for sandbox/virtualized environments and other antimalware processes.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: A FinFisher variant uses a custom packer.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FinFisher checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.[1][5]

Flame.Name: Flame
Flame.Description: Flame is a sophisticated toolkit that has been used to collect information since at least 2010, largely targeting Middle East countries. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Flame can record audio using any existing hardware recording devices.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Authentication Package
Techniques Used.Use: Flame can use Windows Authentication Packages for persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Flame can create backdoor accounts with the login "HelpAssistant" with the Limbo module.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium
Techniques Used.Use: Flame has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Flame can use MS10-061 to exploit a print spooler vulnerability in a remote system with a shared printer in order to move laterally.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Flame contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using autorun functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Rundll32.exe is used as a way of executing Flame at the command-line.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Flame can take regular screenshots when certain applications are open that are sent to the command and control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Flame identifies security software such as antivirus through the Security module.[1][2]

FLASHFLOOD.Name: FLASHFLOOD
FLASHFLOOD.Description: FLASHFLOOD is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD employs the same encoding scheme as SPACESHIP for data it stages. Data is compressed with zlib, and bytes are rotated four times before being XOR'ed with 0x23.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system. FLASHFLOOD will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories. FLASHFLOOD also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on removable media and copies them to a staging area. The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by SPACESHIP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD stages data it copies from the local system or removable drives in the "%WINDIR%\$NtUninstallKB885884$\" directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: FLASHFLOOD achieves persistence by making an entry in the Registry's Run key.[1]

FLIPSIDE.Name: FLIPSIDE
FLIPSIDE.Description: FLIPSIDE is a simple tool similar to Plink that is used by FIN5 to maintain access to victims. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: FLIPSIDE is a simple proxy that creates an outbound RDP connection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FLIPSIDE uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.[1]

Forfiles.Name: Forfiles
Forfiles.Description: Forfiles is a Windows utility commonly used in batch jobs to execute commands on one or more selected files or directories (ex: list all directories in a drive, read the first line of all files created yesterday, etc.). Forfiles can be executed from either the command line, Run window, or batch files/scripts. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Forfiles can be used to act on (ex: copy, move, etc.) files/directories in a system during (ex: copy files into a staging area before).[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Forfiles can be used to locate certain types of files/directories in a system.(ex: locate all files with a specific extension, name, and/or age)[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Indirect Command Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Forfiles can be used to subvert controls and possibly conceal command execution by not directly invoking cmd.[3][4]

FruitFly.Name: FruitFly
FruitFly.Description: FruitFly is designed to spy on mac users  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly looks for specific files and file types.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly will delete files on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly persists via a Launch Agent.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly executes and stores obfuscated Perl scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly has the ability to list processes on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: FruitFly takes screenshots of the user's desktop.[1]

FTP.Name: FTP
FTP.Description: FTP is a utility commonly available with operating systems to transfer information over the File Transfer Protocol (FTP). Adversaries can use it to transfer other tools onto a system or to exfiltrate data. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: FTP operates over ports 21 and 20.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FTP may be used to exfiltrate data separate from the main command and control protocol.[1]

Gazer.Name: Gazer
Gazer.Description: Gazer is a backdoor used by Turla since at least 2016. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer versions are signed with various valid certificates; one was likely faked and issued by Comodo for "Solid Loop Ltd," and another was issued for "Ultimate Computer Support Ltd."[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer identifies a proxy server if it exists and uses it to make HTTP requests.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer uses custom encryption for C2 using 3DES and RSA.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer has commands to delete files and persistence mechanisms from the victim.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: NTFS File Attributes
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer stores configuration items in alternate data streams (ADSs) if the Registry is not accessible.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES. It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer performs thread execution hijacking to inject its orchestrator into a running thread from a remote process. Gazer performs a separate injection of its communication module into an Internet accessible process through which it performs C2.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can execute a task to download a file.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can establish persistence by creating a scheduled task.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screensaver
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can establish persistence through the system screensaver by configuring it to execute the malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu or by modifying existing .lnk files to execute the malware through cmd.exe.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer communicates with its C2 servers over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer obtains the current user's security identifier.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: For early Gazer versions, the compilation timestamp was faked.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Techniques Used.Use: Gazer can establish persistence by setting the value “Shell” with “explorer.exe, %malware_pathfile%” under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.[1]

GeminiDuke.Name: GeminiDuke
GeminiDuke.Description: GeminiDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2009 to 2012. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke collects information on local user accounts from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke collects information from the victim, including installed drivers, programs previously executed by users, programs and services configured to automatically run at startup, files and folders present in any user's home folder, files and folders present in any user's My Documents, programs installed to the Program Files folder, and recently accessed files, folders, and programs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke collects information on running processes and environment variables from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke collects information on network settings and Internet proxy settings from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GeminiDuke collects information on programs and services on the victim that are configured to automatically run at startup.[1]

gh0st.Name: gh0st
gh0st.Description: gh0st is a remote access tool (RAT). The source code is public and it has been used by many groups. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: gh0st RAT is able to open a command shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: A gh0st variant has used DLL side-loading.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: gh0st RAT is able to delete files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: gh0st RAT is able to wipe event logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: The gh0st RAT has a keylogger.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: gh0st RAT is able to list processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: A gh0st variant has used rundll32 for execution.[2]

GLOOXMAIL.Name: GLOOXMAIL
GLOOXMAIL.Description: GLOOXMAIL is malware used by APT1 that mimics legitimate Jabber/XMPP traffic. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: GLOOXMAIL communicates to servers operated by Google using the Jabber/XMPP protocol.[1][2]

Gold Dragon.Name: Gold Dragon
Gold Dragon.Description: Gold Dragon is a Korean-language, data gathering implant that was first observed in the wild in South Korea in July 2017. Gold Dragon was used along with Brave Prince and RunningRAT in operations targeting organizations associated with the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon uses cmd.exe to execute commands for discovery.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon stores information gathered from the endpoint in a file named 1.hwp.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon terminates anti-malware processes if they’re found running on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon lists the directories for Desktop, program files, and the user’s recently accessed files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon deletes one of its files, 2.hwp, from the endpoint after establishing persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon checks the running processes on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon enumerates registry keys with the command regkeyenum and obtains information for the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon establishes persistence in the Startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon can download additional components from the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon checks for anti-malware products and processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon uses HTTP for communication to the control servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon collects endpoint information using the systeminfo command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gold Dragon collects the endpoint victim's username and uses it as a basis for downloading additional components from the C2 server.[1]

Gooligan.Name: Gooligan
Gooligan.Description: Gooligan is a malware family that runs privilege escalation exploits on Android devices and then uses its escalated privileges to steal authentication tokens that can be used to access data from many Google applications. Gooligan has been described as part of the Ghost Push Android malware family. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Gooligan steals authentication tokens that can be used to access data from multiple Google applications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: Gooligan executes Android root exploits.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
Techniques Used.Use: Gooligan can install adware to generate revenue.[1]

GravityRAT.Name: GravityRAT
GravityRAT.Description: GravityRAT is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT executes commands remotely on the infected host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT has been delivered via Word documents using DDE for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: The author of GravityRAT submitted samples to VirusTotal for testing, showing that the author modified the code to try to hide the DDE object in a different part of the document.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT lists the running processes on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT creates a scheduled task to ensure it is re-executed everyday.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT collects the victim IP address, MAC address, as well as the victim account domain name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT uses the netstat command to find open ports on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT collects the victim username along with other account information (account type, description, full name, SID and status).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT has a feature to list the available services on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT can obtain the date and time of a system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT uses port 46769 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: GravityRAT collects various information via WMI requests, including CPU information in the Win32_Processor entry (Processor ID, Name, Manufacturer and the clock speed).[1]

gsecdump.Name: gsecdump
gsecdump.Description: gsecdump is a publicly-available credential dumper used to obtain password hashes and LSA secrets from Windows operating systems. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: gsecdump can dump Windows password hashes and LSA secrets.[1]

H1N1.Name: H1N1
H1N1.Description: H1N1 is a malware variant that has been distributed via a campaign using VBA macros to infect victims. Although it initially had only loader capabilities, it has evolved to include information-stealing functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 bypasses user access control by using a DLL hijacking vulnerability in the Windows Update Standalone Installer (wusa.exe).[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 kills and disables services by using cmd.exe.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 dumps usernames and passwords from Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Outlook.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 kills and disables services for Windows Firewall, Windows Security Center, and Windows Defender.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 deletes shadow copies from the victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 contains a command to download and execute a file from a remotely hosted URL using WinINet HTTP requests.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 has functionality to copy itself to removable media.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 uses a custom packing algorithm.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Taint Shared Content
Techniques Used.Use: H1N1 has functionality to copy itself to network shares.[2]

Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.Name: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit
Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit.Description: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit is a rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team as a method of persistence for remote access software. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Firmware
Techniques Used.Use: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.[1]

HALFBAKED.Name: HALFBAKED
HALFBAKED.Description: HALFBAKED is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can delete a specified file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can execute PowerShell scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can obtain information about running processes on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can obtain screenshots from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: HALFBAKED can use WMI queries to gather system information.[1]

HAMMERTOSS.Name: HAMMERTOSS
HAMMERTOSS.Description: HAMMERTOSS is a backdoor that was used by APT29 in 2015. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Before being appended to image files, HAMMERTOSS commands are encrypted with a key composed of both a hard-coded value and a string contained on that day's tweet. To decrypt the commands, an investigator would need access to the intended malware sample, the day's tweet, and the image file containing the command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: HAMMERTOSS is controlled via commands that are appended to image files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: HAMMERTOSS exfiltrates data by uploading it to accounts created by the actors on Web cloud storage providers for the adversaries to retrieve later.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: HAMMERTOSS is known to use PowerShell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The "Uploader" variant of HAMMERTOSS visits a hard-coded server over HTTP/S to download the images HAMMERTOSS uses to receive commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: The "tDiscoverer" variant of HAMMERTOSS establishes a C2 channel by downloading resources from Web services like Twitter and GitHub. HAMMERTOSS binaries contain an algorithm that generates a different Twitter handle for the malware to check for instructions every day.[1]

HAPPYWORK.Name: HAPPYWORK
HAPPYWORK.Description: Happywork is a downloader used by ScarCruft to target South Korean government and financial victims in November 2016. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: can download and execute a second-stage payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: can collect the victim user name.[1]

HARDRAIN.Name: HARDRAIN
HARDRAIN.Description: HARDRAIN is a Trojan malware variant reportedly used by the North Korean government. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: HARDRAIN uses cmd.exe to execute netshcommands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: HARDRAIN binds and listens on port 443.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: HARDRAIN uses the command cmd.exe /c netsh firewall add portopening TCP 443 "adp" and makes the victim machine function as a proxy server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: HARDRAIN uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: HARDRAIN opens the Windows Firewall to modify incoming connections.[1]

Havij.Name: Havij
Havij.Description: Havij is an automatic SQL Injection tool distributed by the Iranian ITSecTeam security company. Havij has been used by penetration testers and adversaries. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Techniques Used.Use: Havij is used to automate SQL injection.[1]

hcdLoader.Name: hcdLoader
hcdLoader.Description: hcdLoader is a remote access tool (RAT) that has been used by APT18. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: hcdLoader provides command-line access to the compromised system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: hcdLoader installs itself as a service for persistence.[1][2]

HDoor.Name: HDoor
HDoor.Description: HDoor is malware that has been customized and used by the Naikon group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: HDoor kills anti-virus found on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: HDoor scans to identify open ports on the victim.[1]

Helminth.Name: Helminth
Helminth.Description: Helminth is a backdoor that has at least two variants - one written in VBScript and PowerShell that is delivered via a macros in Excel spreadsheets, and one that is a standalone Windows executable. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: A Helminth VBScript receives a batch script to execute a set of commands in a command prompt.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: The executable version of Helminth has a module to log clipboard contents.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth samples have been signed with legitimate, compromised code signing certificates owned by software company AI Squared.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth can provide a remote shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: For C2 over HTTP, Helminth encodes data with base64 and sends it via the "Cookie" field of HTTP requests. For C2 over DNS, Helminth converts ASCII characters into their hexadecimal values and sends the data in cleartext.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth creates folders to store output from batch scripts prior to sending the information to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: The executable version of Helminth has a module to log keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: The Helminth config file is encrypted with RC4.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth has checked for the local admin group domain admin group and Exchange Trusted Subsystem groups using the commands net group Exchange Trusted Subsystem /domain and net group domain admins /domain.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: One version of Helminth uses a PowerShell script.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth has used Tasklist to get information on processes.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut in the Start Menu folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth can download additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth has used a scheduled task for persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: One version of Helminth consists of VBScript and PowerShell scripts. The malware also uses batch scripting.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth can use HTTP or DNS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Helminth encrypts data sent to its C2 server over HTTP with RC4.[1]

Hi-Zor.Name: Hi-Zor
Hi-Zor.Description: Hi-Zor is a remote access tool (RAT) that has characteristics similar to Sakula. It was used in a campaign named INOCNATION. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor has the ability to create a reverse shell.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor communicates with its C2 server over port 443.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor deletes its RAT installer file as it executes its DLL payload file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Multilayer Encryption
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor encrypts C2 traffic with HTTPS and also encodes it with a single-byte XOR key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor uses various XOR techniques to obfuscate its components.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor executes using regsvr32.exe called from the Registry Run Keys / Start Folder persistence mechanism.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor has the ability to upload and download files from its C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Hi-Zor communicates with its C2 server over HTTPS.[2]

HIDEDRV.Name: HIDEDRV
HIDEDRV.Description: HIDEDRV is a rootkit used by APT28. It has been deployed along with Downdelph to execute and hide that malware. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: HIDEDRV injects a DLL for Downdelph into the explorer.exe process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: HIDEDRV is a rootkit that hides certain operating system artifacts.[1]

Hikit.Name: Hikit
Hikit.Description: Hikit is malware that has been used by Axiom for late-stage persistence and exfiltration after the initial compromise. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Hikit supports peer connections.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Hikit performs XOR encryption.[1]

HOMEFRY.Name: HOMEFRY
HOMEFRY.Description: HOMEFRY is a 64-bit Windows password dumper/cracker that has previously been used in conjunction with other Leviathan backdoors. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: uses a command-line interface.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: can perform credential dumping.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Some strings in are obfuscated with XOR x56.[1]

HTRAN.Name: HTRAN
HTRAN.Description: HTRAN is a tool that proxies connections through intermediate hops and aids users in disguising their true geographical location. It can be used by adversaries to hide their location when interacting with the victim networks. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: HTRAN is used for proxying connections to obfuscate command and control infrastructure.[1]

HTTPBrowser.Name: HTTPBrowser
HTTPBrowser.Description: HTTPBrowser is malware that has been used by several threat groups. [1] [2] It is believed to be of Chinese origin. [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser is capable of spawning a reverse shell on a victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
