Techniques Used.Use: One HTTPBrowser variant connected to its C2 server over port 8080.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser has used DLL side-loading.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser is capable of listing files, folders, and drives on a victim.[2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser deletes its original installer file once installation is complete.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser is capable of capturing keystrokes on victims.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser's installer contains a malicious file named navlu.dll to decrypt and run the RAT. navlu.dll is also the name of a legitimate Symantec DLL.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser's code may be obfuscated through structured exception handling and return-oriented programming.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser has established persistence by setting the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run key value for wdm to the path of the executable. It has also used the Registry entry HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run vpdn “%ALLUSERPROFILE%\%APPDATA%\vpdn\VPDN_LU.exe” to establish persistence.[4][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser is capable of writing a file to the compromised system from the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: HTTPBrowser has used HTTP, HTTPS, and DNS for command and control.[2][1]

httpclient.Name: httpclient
httpclient.Description: httpclient is malware used by Putter Panda. It is a simple tool that provides a limited range of functionality, suggesting it is likely used as a second-stage or supplementary/backup tool. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: httpclient opens cmd.exe on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: httpclient encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: httpclient uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

HummingBad.Name: HummingBad
HummingBad.Description: HummingBad is a family of Android malware that generates fraudulent advertising revenue and has the ability to obtain root access on older, vulnerable versions of Android. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: HummingBad can exploit unfixed vulnerabilities in older Android versions to root victim phones.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
Techniques Used.Use: In July 2016, HummingBad generated more than $300,000 per month in revenue from installing fraudulent apps and displaying malicious advertisements.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Manipulate App Store Rankings or Ratings
Techniques Used.Use: HummingBad can create fraudulent statistics inside the official Google Play Store.[1]

HummingWhale.Name: HummingWhale
HummingWhale.Description: HummingWhale is an Android malware family that performs ad fraud. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
Techniques Used.Use: HummingWhale generates revenue by displaying fraudulent ads and automatically installing apps. When victims try to close the ads, HummingWhale runs in a virtual machine, creating a fake ID that allows the perpetrators to generate revenue.[1]

Hydraq.Name: Hydraq
Hydraq.Description: Hydraq is a data-theft trojan first used by Elderwood in the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora, though variations of this trojan have been used in more recent campaigns by other Chinese actors, possibly including APT17. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can adjust token privileges.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq C2 traffic is encrypted using bitwise NOT and XOR operations.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can read data from files.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through Module Load
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can load and call DLL functions.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq connects to a predefined domain on port 443 to exfil gathered information.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can check for the existence of files, including its own components, as well as retrieve a list of logical drives.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can clear all system event logs.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a Registry subkey to register its created service, and can also uninstall itself later by deleting this value. Hydraq's backdoor also enables remote attackers to modify and delete subkeys.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates new services to establish persistence.[3][9][10]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq uses basic obfuscation in the form of spaghetti code.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor processes.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files and additional malware components.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq includes a component based on the code of VNC that can stream a live feed of the desktop of an infected host.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq uses svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL included in a new service group.[10]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve IP addresses of compromised machines.[3][9]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Hydraq creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor services.[3][9]

ifconfig.Name: ifconfig
ifconfig.Description: ifconfig is a Unix-based utility used to gather information about and interact with the TCP/IP settings on a system. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ifconfig can be used to display adapter configuration on Unix systems, including information for TCP/IP, DNS, and DHCP.

iKitten.Name: iKitten
iKitten.Description: iKitten is a macOS exfiltration agent  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten will zip up the /Library/Keychains directory before exfiltrating it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Prompt
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten prompts the user for their credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Keychain
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten collects the keychains on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten lists the current processes running.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rc.common
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: iKitten will look for the current IP address.[1]

InnaputRAT.Name: InnaputRAT
InnaputRAT.Description: InnaputRAT is a remote access tool that can exfiltrate files from a victim’s machine. InnaputRAT has been seen out in the wild since 2016. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT launches a shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT uses the API call ShellExecuteW for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT has a command to delete files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT variants have attempted to appear legitimate by using the file names SafeApp.exe and NeutralApp.exe, as well as by adding a new service named OfficeUpdateService.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Some InnaputRAT variants create a new Windows service to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Some InnaputRAT variants establish persistence by modifying the Registry key HKU\\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run:%appdata%\NeutralApp\NeutralApp.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT gathers volume drive information and system information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: InnaputRAT uses port 52100 and 5876 for C2 communications.[1]

InvisiMole.Name: InvisiMole
InvisiMole.Description: InvisiMole is a modular spyware program that has been used by threat actors since at least 2013. InvisiMole has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole has a command to list account information on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can record sound using input audio devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Each time a new drive is inserted, InvisiMole generates a list of all files on the drive and stores it in an encrypted file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can bypass UAC and create an elevated COM object to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can launch a remote shell to execute commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole uses port 80 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can function as a proxy to create a serve that relays communication between the client and C&C server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole communicates with its C2 servers through a TCP socket.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole uses variations of a simple XOR encryption routine for C&C communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole uses WinRAR to compress data that is intended to be exfiltrated.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole uses a variation of the XOR cipher to encrypt files before exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole determines a working directory where it stores all the gathered data about the compromised machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can decrypt, unpack and load a DLL from its resources.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole has a command to disable routing and the Firewall on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can lists information about files in a directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole has a command to delete a file and deletes files after they have been successfully uploaded to C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole saves one of its files as mpr.dll in the Windows folder, masquerading as a legitimate library file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole has a command to create, set, copy, or delete a specified Registry key or value.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can gather network share information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole obtains a list of running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can enumerate Registry values, keys, and data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can upload files to the victim's machine for operations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can capture screenshots of not only the entire screen, but of each separate window open, in case they are overlapping.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole uses HTTP for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can gather information on the mapped drives, OS version, computer name, and memory size.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole gathers informatin on the IP forwarding table, MAC address, and network SSID.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole lists local users and session information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can obtain running services on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole gathers the local system time from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole samples were timestomped by the authors by setting the PE timestamps to all zero values. InvisiMole also has a built-in command to modify file times.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: InvisiMole can remotely activate the victim’s webcam to capture content.[1]

Invoke-PSImage.Name: Invoke-PSImage
Invoke-PSImage.Description: Invoke-PSImage takes a PowerShell script and embeds the bytes of the script into the pixels of a PNG image. It generates a one liner for executing either from a file of from the web. Example of usage is embedding the PowerShell code from the Invoke-Mimikatz module and embed it into an image file. By calling the image file from a macro for example, the macro will download the picture and execute the PowerShell code, which in this case will dump the passwords. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Invoke-PSImage can be used to embed a PowerShell script within the pixels of a PNG file.[1]

ipconfig.Name: ipconfig
ipconfig.Description: ipconfig is a Windows utility that can be used to find information about a system's TCP/IP, DNS, DHCP, and adapter configuration. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ipconfig can be used to display adapter configuration on Windows systems, including information for TCP/IP, DNS, and DHCP.

ISMInjector.Name: ISMInjector
ISMInjector.Description: ISMInjector is a Trojan used to install another OilRig backdoor, ISMAgent. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: ISMInjector uses the certutil command to decode a payload file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: ISMInjector is obfuscated with the off-the-shelf SmartAssembly .NET obfuscator created by red-gate.com.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: ISMInjector hollows out a newly created process RegASM.exe and injects its payload into the hollowed process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: ISMInjector creates scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[1]

Ixeshe.Name: Ixeshe
Ixeshe.Description: Ixeshe is a malware family that has been used since 2009 to attack targets in East Asia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: The Ixeshe malware uses custom Base64 encoding schemes to obfuscate data command and control traffic in the message body of HTTP requests.[1]

Janicab.Name: Janicab
Janicab.Description: Janicab is an OS X trojan that relied on a valid developer ID and oblivious users to install it. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Janicab captured audio and sent it out to a C2 server.[2][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Janicab used a valid AppleDeveloperID to sign the code to get past security restrictions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Job Scheduling
Techniques Used.Use: Janicab used a cron job for persistence on Mac devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Janicab captured screenshots and sent them out to a C2 server.[2][1]

JHUHUGIT.Name: JHUHUGIT
JHUHUGIT.Description: JHUHUGIT is malware used by APT28. It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. [1] [2] [3] [4]
JHUHUGIT.Aliases: JHUHUGIT, Seduploader, JKEYSKW, Sednit, GAMEFISH, SofacyCarberp

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: A JHUHUGIT variant accesses a screenshot saved in the clipboard and converts it to a JPG image.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: A JHUHUGIT variant encodes C2 POST data base64.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has exploited CVE-2015-1701 and CVE-2015-2387 to escalate privileges.[3][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: The JHUHUGIT dropper can delete itself from the victim. Another JHUHUGIT variant has the capability to delete specified files.[3][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Logon Scripts
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has registered a Windows shell script under the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has registered itself as a service to establish persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Many strings in JHUHUGIT are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT obtains a list of running processes on the victim.[3][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has used a Registry Run key to establish persistence by executing JavaScript code within the rundll32.exe process.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT can retrieve an additional payload from its C2 server.[3][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT is executed using rundll32.exe.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT has registered itself as a scheduled task to run each time the current user logs in.[3][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: A JHUHUGIT variant takes screenshots by simulating the user pressing the "Take Screenshot" key (VK_SCREENSHOT), accessing the screenshot saved in the clipboard, and converting it to a JPG image.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT variants have communicated with C2 servers over HTTP and HTTPS.[3][7][5]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JHUHUGIT obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum. Another JHUHUGIT variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.[3][7]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A JHUHUGIT variant gathers network interface card information.[5]

JPIN.Name: JPIN
JPIN.Description: JPIN is a custom-built backdoor family used by PLATINUM. Evidence suggests developers of JPIN and Dipsind code bases were related in some way. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: BITS Jobs
Techniques Used.Use: A JPIN variant downloads the backdoor payload via the BITS service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN lower disable security settings by changing Registry keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can enumerate drives and their types. It can also change file permissions using cacls.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN's installer/uninstaller component deletes itself if it encounters a version of Windows earlier than Windows XP or identifies security-related processes running.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Permissions Modification
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN contains a custom keylogger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A JPIN uses a encrypted and compressed payload that is disguised as a bitmap within the resource section of the installer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can obtain the victim user name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can list running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can inject content into lsass.exe to load a module.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can enumerate Registry keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can download files and upgrade itself.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN checks for the presence of certain security-related processes and deletes its installer/uninstaller component if it identifies any of them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can communicate over FTP and send email over SMTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can obtain network information, including DNS, IP, and proxies.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can obtain the victim user name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: JPIN can list running services.[1]

jRAT.Name: jRAT
jRAT.Description: jRAT is a cross-platform remote access tool that was first observed in November 2017. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT has a function to delete files from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT has the capability to log keystrokes from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT’s Java payload is encrypted with AES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT can download and execute files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT has the capability to take screenshots of the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT uses WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT has the capability to access the webcam on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: jRAT uses WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.[1]

Judy.Name: Judy
Judy.Description: Judy is auto-clicking adware that was distributed through multiple apps in the Google Play Store. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: Judy bypasses Google Play's protections by downloading a malicious payload at runtime after installation.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
Techniques Used.Use: Judy uses infected devices to generate fraudulent clicks on advertisements to generate revenue.[1]

KARAE.Name: KARAE
KARAE.Description: KARAE is a backdoor typically used by APT37 as first-stage malware. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: KARAE was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: KARAE can upload and download files, including second-stage malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KARAE can collect system information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: KARAE can use public cloud-based storage providers for command and control.[1]

Kasidet.Name: Kasidet
Kasidet.Description: Kasidet is a backdoor that has been dropped by using malicious VBA macros. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet can execute commands using cmd.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to change firewall settings to allow a plug-in to be downloaded.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to search for a given filename on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to initiate keylogging.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to search for a given process name in processes currently running in the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet creates a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to download and execute additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to initiate keylogging and screen captures.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to identify any anti-virus installed on the infected system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kasidet has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.[1]

Kazuar.Name: Kazuar
Kazuar.Description: Kazuar is a fully featured, multi-platform backdoor Trojan written using the Microsoft .NET framework. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information on local groups and members on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information about opened windows.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar uses cmd.exe and /bin/bash to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar encodes communications to the C2 server in Base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar stages command output and collected data in files before exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar can delete files and optionally overwrite with random data beforehand.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar can install itself as a new service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector. Kazuar also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information about local groups and members.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar obtains a list of running processes through WMI querying and the ps command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: If running in a Windows environment, Kazuar saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload. Kazuar can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar adds a sub-key under several Registry run keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar downloads additional plug-ins to load on the victim’s machine, including the ability to upgrade and replace its own binary.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar can sleep for a specific time and be set to communicate at specific intervals.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar captures screenshots of the victim’s screen.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar uses HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and FTPS to communicate with the C2 server. Kazuar can also act as a webserver and listen for inbound HTTP requests through an exposed API.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information on the system and local drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information about network adapters.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar gathers information on users.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar captures images from the webcam.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Kazuar has used compromised WordPress blogs as C2 servers.[1]

Keydnap.Name: Keydnap
Keydnap.Description: This piece of malware steals the content of the user's keychain while maintaining a permanent backdoor  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: Input Prompt
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap prompts the users for credentials.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap uses a Launch Agent to persist.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-hop Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap uses a copy of tor2web proxy for HTTPS communications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap uses Python for scripting to execute additional commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Securityd Memory
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap uses the keychaindump project to read securityd memory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Setuid and Setgid
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap adds the setuid flag to a binary so it can easily elevate in the future.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Space after Filename
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap puts a space after a false .jpg extension so that execution actually goes through the Terminal.app program.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Keydnap uses HTTPS for command and control.[2]

KEYMARBLE.Name: KEYMARBLE
KEYMARBLE.Description: KEYMARBLE is a Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE can execute shell commands using cmd.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE uses port 443 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE uses a customized XOR algorithm to encrypt C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE has a command to search for files on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE has the capability to delete files off the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE has a command to create Registry entries for storing data under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WABE\DataPath.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE can obtain a list of running processes on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE can upload files to the victim’s machine and can download additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KEYMARBLE gathers the MAC address of the victim’s machine.[1]

KeyRaider.Name: KeyRaider
KeyRaider.Description: KeyRaider is malware that steals Apple account credentials and other data from jailbroken iOS devices. It also has ransomware functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Lock User Out of Device
Techniques Used.Use: KeyRaider has built-in functionality to lock victims out of devices and hold them for ransom.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Traffic Capture or Redirection
Techniques Used.Use: Most KeyRaider samples hook SSLRead and SSLWrite functions in the itunesstored process to intercept device communication with the Apple App Store.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Most KeyRaider samples search to find the Apple account's username, password and device's GUID in data being transferred.[1]

Koadic.Name: Koadic
Koadic.Description: Koadic is a Windows post-exploitation framework and penetration testing tool. Koadic is publicly available on GitHub and the tool is executed via the command-line. Koadic has several options for staging payloads and creating implants. Koadic performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic has 2 methods for elevating integrity. It can bypass UAC through eventvwr.exe and sdclt.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can retrieve the current content of the user clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can open an interactive command-shell to perform command line functions on victim machines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can gather hashed passwords by dumping SAM/SECURITY hive and gathers domain controller hashes from NTDS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can download files off the target system to send back to the server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Mshta
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can use MSHTA to serve additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can scan for open TCP ports on the target network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can scan local network for open SMB.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can perform process injection by using a reflective DLL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can use Regsvr32 to execute additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can enable remote desktop on the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can download additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can use Rundll32 to execute additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic performs most of its operations using Windows Script Host (Jscript and VBScript) and runs arbitrary shellcode .[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can run a command on another machine using PsExec.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can use SSL and TLS for communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can retrieve information about the Windows domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can identify logged in users across the domain and views user sessions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: Koadic can use WMI to execute commands.[1]

Komplex.Name: Komplex
Komplex.Description: Komplex is a backdoor that has been used by APT28 on OS X and appears to be developed in a similar manner to XAgentOSX [1] [2].

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Komplex C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: The Komplex trojan supports file deletion.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: The Komplex payload is stored in a hidden directory at /Users/Shared/.local/kextd.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: The Komplex trojan creates a persistent launch agent called with $HOME/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist with launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The OsInfo function in Komplex collects a running process list.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Komplex C2 channel uses HTTP POST requests.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The OsInfo function in Komplex collects the current running username.[2]

KOMPROGO.Name: KOMPROGO
KOMPROGO.Description: KOMPROGO is a signature backdoor used by APT32 that is capable of process, file, and registry management. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: KOMPROGO is capable of creating a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: KOMPROGO is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: KOMPROGO is capable of running WMI queries.[1]

Kwampirs.Name: Kwampirs
Kwampirs.Description: Kwampirs is a backdoor Trojan used by Orangeworm. It has been found on machines which had software installed for the use and control of high-tech imaging devices such as X-Ray and MRI machines. [1]
Kwampirs.Contributors: Elger Vinicius S. Rodrigues, @elgervinicius, CYBINT Centre

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of accounts with the command net users.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: Before writing to disk, Kwampirs inserts a randomly generated string into the middle of the decrypted payload in an attempt to evade hash-based detections.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs decrypts and extracts a copy of its main DLL payload when executing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP\[RANDOM].tmp".[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs establishes persistence by adding a new service with the display name "WMI Performance Adapter Extension" in an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate WMI service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of network shares with the command net share.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs creates a new service named WmiApSrvEx to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Password Policy Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects password policy information with the command net accounts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects lists of local accounts with administrative access, local group user accounts, and domain local groups with the commands net localgroup administrators, net localgroup users, and net localgroup /domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /v.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs downloads additional files from C2 servers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of available servers with the command net view.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs uses rundll32.exe in a Registry value added to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands systeminfo, net config workstation, hostname, ver, set, and date /t.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects network adapter and interface information by using the commands ipconfig /all, arp -a and route print. It also collects the system's MAC address with getmac and domain configuration with net config workstation.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of active and listening connections by using the command netstat -nao as well as a list of available network mappings with net use.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects registered owner details by using the commands systeminfo and net config workstation.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs collects a list of running services with the command tasklist /svc.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Kwampirs copies itself over network shares to move laterally on a victim network.[1]

Linfo.Name: Linfo
Linfo.Description: Linfo is a rootkit trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can start a remote shell.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can obtain data from local systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can list contents of drives and search for files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve a list of running processes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change the frequency at which compromised hosts contact remote C2 infrastructure.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.[2]

LOWBALL.Name: LOWBALL
LOWBALL.Description: LOWBALL is malware used by admin@338. It was used in August 2015 in email messages targeting Hong Kong-based media organizations. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: LOWBALL command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: LOWBALL uses the Dropbox API to request two files, one of which is the same file as the one dropped by the malicious email attachment. This is most likely meant to be a mechanism to update the compromised host with a new version of the LOWBALL malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: LOWBALL command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: LOWBALL uses the Dropbox cloud storage service for command and control.[1]

Lslsass.Name: Lslsass
Lslsass.Description: Lslsass is a publicly-available tool that can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Lslsass can dump active logon session password hashes from the lsass process.[1]

Lurid.Name: Lurid
Lurid.Description: Lurid is a malware family that has been used by several groups, including PittyTiger, in targeted attacks as far back as 2006. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Lurid performs XOR encryption.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Lurid can compress data before sending it.[2]

MacSpy.Name: MacSpy
MacSpy.Description: MacSpy is a malware-as-a-service offered on the darkweb  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy can record the sounds from microphones on a computer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy can steal clipboard contents.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy deletes any temporary files it creates[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy stores itself in ~/Library/.DS_Stores/ [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy captures keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy persists via a Launch Agent.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-hop Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy uses Tor for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy can capture screenshots of the desktop over multiple monitors.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MacSpy uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

Marcher.Name: Marcher
Marcher.Description: Marcher is Android malware that is used for financial fraud. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Abuse Device Administrator Access to Prevent Removal
Techniques Used.Use: Marcher requests Android Device Administrator access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: Marcher is delivered via a link sent by SMS or email, including instructions advising the user to modify their Android device security settings to enable apps to be installed from "Unknown Sources."[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Interface Spoofing
Techniques Used.Use: Marcher attempts to overlay itself on top of legitimate banking apps in an effort to capture user credentials. Marcher also attempts to overlay itself on top of legitimate apps such as the Google Play Store in an effort to capture user credit card information.[1]

Matroyshka.Name: Matroyshka
Matroyshka.Description: Matroyshka is a malware framework used by CopyKittens that consists of a dropper, loader, and RAT. It has multiple versions; v1 was seen in the wild from July 2016 until January 2017. v2 has fewer commands and other minor differences. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka is capable of providing Meterpreter shell access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka is capable of stealing Outlook passwords.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka is capable of keylogging.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka uses reflective DLL injection to inject the malicious library and execute the RAT.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka can establish persistence by adding Registry Run keys.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key value for execution as part of its persistence mechanism.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka can establish persistence by adding a Scheduled Task named "Microsoft Boost Kernel Optimization".[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka is capable of performing screen captures.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Matroyshka uses DNS for C2.[1][2]

MazarBOT.Name: MazarBOT
MazarBOT.Description: MazarBOT is Android malware that was distributed via SMS in Denmark in 2016. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: MazarBOT can intercept two-factor authentication codes sent by online banking apps.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: MazarBOT is delivered via an unsolicited text message containing a link to a web download URI.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Premium SMS Toll Fraud
Techniques Used.Use: MazarBOT can send messages to premium-rate numbers.[1]

meek.Name: meek
meek.Description: meek is an open-source Tor plugin that tunnels Tor traffic through HTTPS connections.

Techniques Used.Name: Domain Fronting
Techniques Used.Use: meek uses Domain Fronting to disguise the destination of network traffic as another server that is hosted in the same Content Delivery Network (CDN) as the intended desitnation.

Mimikatz.Name: Mimikatz
Mimikatz.Description: Mimikatz is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords, along with many other features that make it useful for testing the security of networks. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: The Mimikatz credential dumper has been extended to include Skeleton Key domain controller authentication bypass functionality. The LSADUMP::ChangeNTLM and LSADUMP::SetNTLM modules can also manipulate the password hash of an account without knowing the clear text value.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources. It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from the LSA, SAM table, credential vault, DCSync/NetSync, and DPAPI.[1][4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz's DPAPI module can harvest protected credentials stored and/or cached by browsers and other user applications by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.[2][5]

Techniques Used.Name: DCShadow
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz’s LSADUMP::DCShadow module can be used to make AD updates by temporarily setting a computer to be a DC.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz's SEKURLSA::Pth module can impersonate a user, with only a password hash, to execute arbitrary commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Ticket
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz’s LSADUMP::DCSync, KERBEROS::Golden, and KERBEROS::PTT modules implement the three steps required to extract the krbtgt account hash and create/use Kerberos tickets.[2][6][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Private Keys
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz's CRYPTO::Extract module can extract keys by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Support Provider
Techniques Used.Use: The Mimikatz credential dumper contains an implementation of an SSP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: SID-History Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Mimikatz's MISC::AddSid module can appended any SID or user/group account to a user's SID-History. Mimikatz also utilizes SID-History Injection to expand the scope of other components such as generated Kerberos Golden Tickets and DCSync beyond a single domain.[2][6]

MimiPenguin.Name: MimiPenguin
MimiPenguin.Description: MimiPenguin is a credential dumper, similar to Mimikatz, designed specifically for Linux platforms. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: MimiPenguin can dump process memory and extract clear-text credentials.[1]

Miner-C.Name: Miner-C
Miner-C.Description: Miner-C is malware that mines victims for the Monero cryptocurrency. It has targeted FTP servers and Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices to spread. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Taint Shared Content
Techniques Used.Use: Miner-C copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.[1]

MiniDuke.Name: MiniDuke
MiniDuke.Description: MiniDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015. The MiniDuke toolset consists of multiple downloader and backdoor components. The loader has been used with other MiniDuke components as well as in conjunction with CosmicDuke and PinchDuke. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: MiniDuke uses Google Search to identify C2 servers if its primary C2 method via Twitter is not working.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: MiniDuke can download additional encrypted backdoors onto the victim via GIF files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MiniDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Some MiniDuke components use Twitter to initially obtain the address of a C2 server or as a backup if no hard-coded C2 server responds.[1][2]

MirageFox.Name: MirageFox
MirageFox.Description: MirageFox is a remote access tool used against Windows systems. It appears to be an upgraded version of a tool known as Mirage, which is a RAT believed to originate in 2012. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox has the capability to execute commands using cmd.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox uses port 80 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox has a function for decrypting data containing C2 configuration information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MirageFox can gather the username from the victim’s machine.[1]

Mis-Type.Name: Mis-Type
Mis-Type.Description: Mis-Type is a backdoor hybrid that was used by Dust Storm in 2012. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c net user {Username}.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type uses cmd.exe to run commands for enumerating the host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type communicates over common ports such as TCP 80, 443, and 25.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}.”[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The initial beacon packet for Mis-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type may create a file containing the results of the command cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mis-Type runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.[1]

Misdat.Name: Misdat
Misdat.Description: Misdat is a backdoor that was used by Dust Storm from 2010 to 2011. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat is capable of providing shell functionality to the attacker to execute commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat network traffic communicates over common ports like 80, 443, or 1433.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat network traffic communicates over a raw socket.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat network traffic is Base64-encoded plaintext.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat is capable of deleting the backdoor file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat is capable of deleting Registry keys used for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat saves itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat is capable of downloading files from the C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Misdat network traffic communicates over a raw socket.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The initial beacon packet for Misdat contains the operating system version of the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Many Misdat samples were programmed using Borland Delphi, which will mangle the default PE compile timestamp of a file.[1]

Mivast.Name: Mivast
Mivast.Description: Mivast is a backdoor that has been used by Deep Panda. It was reportedly used in the Anthem breach. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Mivast has the capability to open a remote shell and run basic commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Mivast communicates over port 80 for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Mivast has the capability to gather NTLM password information.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Mivast creates the following Registry entry: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Micromedia.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Mivast has the capability to download and execute .exe files.[2]

MobileOrder.Name: MobileOrder
MobileOrder.Description: MobileOrder is a Trojan intended to compromise Android mobile devices. It has been used by Scarlet Mimic. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Browser Bookmark Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server victim browser bookmarks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder exfiltrates data collected from the victim mobile device.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder has a command to upload information about all running processes to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder has a command to download a file from the C2 server to the victim mobile device's SD card.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder uses AES to encrypt C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: MobileOrder communicates with its C2 server over TCP port 3728.[1]

MoonWind.Name: MoonWind
MoonWind.Description: MoonWind is a remote access tool (RAT) that was used in 2016 to target organizations in Thailand. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind can execute commands via an interactive command shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind communicates over ports 80, 443, 53, and 8080 via raw sockets instead of the protocols usually associated with the ports.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind completes network communication via raw sockets.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind saves information from its keylogging routine as a .zip file in the present working directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind has a command to return a directory listing for a specified directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind can delete itself or specified files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind has a keylogger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind installs itself as a new service with automatic startup to establish persistence. The service checks every 60 seconds to determine if the malware is running; if not, it will spawn a new instance.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind obtains the number of removable drives from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind has a command to return a list of running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind uses batch scripts for various purposes, including to restart and uninstall itself.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a static key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind completes network communication via raw sockets.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind can obtain the victim hostname, Windows version, RAM amount, number of drives, and screen resolution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind obtains the victim IP address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind obtains the victim username.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: MoonWind obtains the victim's current time.[1]

More_eggs.Name: More_eggs
More_eggs.Description: More_eggs is a JScript backdoor used by Cobalt Group. Its name was given based on the variable "More_eggs" being present in its code. There are at least two different versions of the backdoor being used, version 2.0 and version 4.4. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs can remove itself from a system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs can download and launch additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs can obtain information on installed anti-malware programs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs uses HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs has the capability to gather the IP address from the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: More_eggs has the capability to gather the username from the victim's machine.[1]

Mosquito.Name: Mosquito
Mosquito.Description: Mosquito is a Win32 backdoor that has been used by Turla. Mosquito is made up of three parts: the installer, the launcher, and the backdoor. The main backdoor is called CommanderDLL and is launched by the loader program. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito executes cmd.exe and uses a pipe to read the results and send back the output to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito uses COM hijacking as a method of persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito uses a custom encryption algorithm, which consists of XOR and a stream that is similar to the Blum Blum Shub algorithm.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito leverages the CreateProcess() and LoadLibrary() calls to execute files with the .dll and .exe extensions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito deletes files using DeleteFileW API call.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito stores configuration values under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\[dllname] and modifies Registry keys under HKCR\CLSID\...\InprocServer32with a path to the launcher.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito’s installer is obfuscated with a custom crypter to obfuscate the installer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito can launch PowerShell Scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito runs tasklist to obtain running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito establishes persistence under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Run auto_update.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito can upload and download files to the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito's launcher uses rundll32.exe in a Registry Key value to start the main backdoor capability.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito's installer searches the Registry and system to see if specific antivirus tools are installed on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito uses the ipconfig command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito runs whoami on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: Mosquito's installer uses WMI to search for antivirus display names.[1]

MURKYTOP.Name: MURKYTOP
MURKYTOP.Description: MURKYTOP is a reconnaissance tool used by Leviathan. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to retrieve information about users on remote hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: uses the command-line interface.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to delete local files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to scan for open ports on hosts in a connected network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to retrieve information about shares on remote hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to retrieve information about groups.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to identify remote hosts on connected networks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.[1]

Naid.Name: Naid
Naid.Description: Naid is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Naid connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Naid connects to C2 infrastructure and establishes backdoors over a custom communications protocol.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Naid creates Registry entries that store information about a created service and point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Naid creates a new service to establish.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Naid collects a unique identifier (UID) from a compromised host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Naid collects the domain name from a compromised host.[2]

NanHaiShu.Name: NanHaiShu
NanHaiShu.Description: NanHaiShu is a remote access tool and JScript backdoor used by Leviathan. NanHaiShu has been used to target government and private-sector organizations that have relations to the South China Sea dispute. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu can change Internet Explorer settings to reduce warnings about malware activity.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu launches a script to delete their original decoy file to cover tracks.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Mshta
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu uses mshta.exe to load its program and files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu encodes files in Base64.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu modifies the %regrun% Registry to point itself to an autostart mechanism.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu can download additional files from URLs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu executes additional Jscript and VBScript code on the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu uses DNS for the C2 communications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu can gather the victim computer name and serial number.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu can gather information about the victim proxy server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NanHaiShu collects the username from the victim.[2]

NavRAT.Name: NavRAT
NavRAT.Description: NavRAT is a remote access tool designed to upload, download, and execute files. It has been observed in attacks targeting South Korea. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT leverages cmd.exe to perform discovery techniques.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT writes multiple outputs to a TMP file using the >> method.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT logs the keystrokes on the targeted system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT uses tasklist /v to check running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT creates a Registry key to ensure a file gets executed upon reboot in order to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT can download files remotely.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT loads malicious shellcode and executes it in memory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT uses the email platform, Naver, for C2 communications, leveraging SMTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NavRAT uses systeminfo on a victim’s machine.[1]

nbtstat.Name: nbtstat
nbtstat.Description: nbtstat is a utility used to troubleshoot NetBIOS name resolution. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: nbtstat can be used to discover local NetBIOS domain names.

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: nbtstat can be used to discover current NetBIOS sessions.

NDiskMonitor.Name: NDiskMonitor
NDiskMonitor.Description: NDiskMonitor is a custom backdoor written in .NET that appears to be unique to Patchwork. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NDiskMonitor can obtain a list of all files and directories as well as logical drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: NDiskMonitor can download and execute a file from given URL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: NDiskMonitor uses AES to encrypt certain information sent over its C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NDiskMonitor obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NDiskMonitor obtains the victim username and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.[1]

Nerex.Name: Nerex
Nerex.Description: Nerex is a Trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Nerex drops a signed Microsoft DLL to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Nerex creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Nerex creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
