Techniques Used.Use: Nerex creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files onto a compromised host.[3]

Net.Name: Net
Net.Description:
The Net utility is a component of the Windows operating system. It is used in command-line operations for control of users, groups, services, and network connections. [1]
Net has a great deal of functionality, [2] much of which is useful for an adversary, such as gathering system and network information for Discovery, moving laterally through Windows Admin Shares using net use commands, and interacting with services.

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Commands under net user can be used in Net to gather information about and manipulate user accounts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: The net user username \password and net user username \password \domain commands in Net can be used to create a local or domain account respectively.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Connection Removal
Techniques Used.Use: The net use \\system\share /delete command can be used in Net to remove an established connection to a network share.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The net view \\remotesystem and net share commands in Net can be used to find shared drives and directories on remote and local systems respectively.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Password Policy Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The net accounts and net accounts /domain commands with Net can be used to obtain password policy information.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Commands such as net group and net localgroup can be used in Net to gather information about and manipulate groups.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Commands such as net view can be used in Net to gather information about available remote systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: The net start and net stop commands can be used in Net to execute or stop Windows services.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Commands such as net use and net session can be used in Net to gather information about network connections from a particular host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The net start command can be used in Net to find information about Windows services.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The net time command can be used in Net to determine the local or remote system time.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Lateral movement can be done with Net through net use commands to connect to the on remote systems.[2]

Net Crawler.Name: Net Crawler
Net Crawler.Description: Net Crawler is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using PsExec to execute a copy of Net Crawler. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Net Crawler uses a list of known credentials gathered through credential dumping to guess passwords to accounts as it spreads throughout a network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Net Crawler uses credential dumpers such as Mimikatz and Windows Credential Editor to extract cached credentials from Windows systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Net Crawler uses PsExec to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Net Crawler uses Windows admin shares to establish authenticated sessions to remote systems over SMB as part of lateral movement.[1]

NETEAGLE.Name: NETEAGLE
NETEAGLE.Description: NETEAGLE is a backdoor developed by APT30 with compile dates as early as 2008. It has two main variants known as “Scout” and “Norton.” [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE allows adversaries to execute shell commands on the infected host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: If NETEAGLE does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, NETEAGLE will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE is capable of reading files over the C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, NETEAGLE will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system. It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE can send process listings over the C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: The "SCOUT" variant of NETEAGLE achieves persistence by adding itself to the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, NETEAGLE will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000. NETEAGLE will also use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and Port Number pair to connect to for further C2. Adversaries can also use NETEAGLE to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: NETEAGLE will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: If NETEAGLE does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number, NETEAGLE will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.[1]

netsh.Name: netsh
netsh.Description: netsh is a scripting utility used to interact with networking components on local or remote systems. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: netsh can be used to set up a proxy tunnel to allow remote host access to an infected host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: netsh can be used to disable local firewall settings.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Netsh Helper DLL
Techniques Used.Use: netsh can be used as a persistence proxy technique to execute a helper DLL when netsh.exe is executed.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: netsh can be used to discover system firewall settings.[1][3]

netstat.Name: netstat
netstat.Description: netstat is an operating system utility that displays active TCP connections, listening ports, and network statistics. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: netstat can be used to enumerate local network connections, including active TCP connections and other network statistics.[1]

NetTraveler.Name: NetTraveler
NetTraveler.Description: NetTraveler is malware that has been used in multiple cyber espionage campaigns for basic surveillance of victims. The earliest known samples have timestamps back to 2005, and the largest number of observed samples were created between 2010 and 2013. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NetTraveler reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: NetTraveler contains a keylogger.[1]

NETWIRE.Name: NETWIRE
NETWIRE.Description: NETWIRE is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: The NETWIRE client has been signed by fake and invalid digital certificates.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: NETWIRE can perform keylogging.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: NETWIRE creates a Registry start-up entry to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: NETWIRE can capture the victim's screen.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: NETWIRE can discover and collect victim system information.[2]

Nidiran.Name: Nidiran
Nidiran.Description: Nidiran is a custom backdoor developed and used by Suckfly. It has been delivered via strategic web compromise. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Nidiran communicates with its C2 domain over ports 443 and 8443.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Nidiran can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager), which mimics the legitimate Microsoft database by the same name.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Nidiran can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager).[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Nidiran can download and execute files.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Nidiran uses RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[2]

NotCompatible.Name: NotCompatible
NotCompatible.Description: NotCompatible is an Android malware family that was used between at least 2014 and 2016. It has multiple variants that have become more sophisticated over time. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit Enterprise Resources
Techniques Used.Use: NotCompatible has the capability to exploit systems on an enterprise network.[1]

OBAD.Name: OBAD
OBAD.Description: OBAD is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Abuse Device Administrator Access to Prevent Removal
Techniques Used.Use: OBAD abuses device administrator access to make it more difficult for users to remove the application.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: OBAD contains encrypted code along with an obfuscated decryption routine to make it difficult to analyze.[1]

OLDBAIT.Name: OLDBAIT
OLDBAIT.Description: OLDBAIT is a credential harvester used by APT28. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: OLDBAIT collects credentials from Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Eudora, and several email clients.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: OLDBAIT installs itself in %ALLUSERPROFILE%\\Application Data\Microsoft\MediaPlayer\updatewindws.exe; the directory name is missing a space and the file name is missing the letter "o."[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: OLDBAIT obfuscates internal strings and unpacks them at startup.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OLDBAIT can use HTTP or SMTP for C2.[1]

OldBoot.Name: OldBoot
OldBoot.Description: OldBoot is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify OS Kernel or Boot Partition
Techniques Used.Use: OldBoot uses escalated privileges to modify the init script on the device's boot partition to maintain persistence.[1]

OnionDuke.Name: OnionDuke
OnionDuke.Description: OnionDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2013 to 2015. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: OnionDuke steals credentials from its victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OnionDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: OnionDuke uses Twitter as a backup C2 method. It also has a module designed to post messages to the Russian VKontakte social media site.[1]

OopsIE.Name: OopsIE
OopsIE.Description: OopsIE is a Trojan used by OilRig to remotely execute commands as well as upload/download files to/from victims. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE uses the command prompt to execute commands on the victim's machine.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE compresses collected files with both the GZipStream class and a simple character replacement scheme before sending them to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE encodes data in hexadecimal format over the C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE stages the output from command execution and collected files in specific folders before exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE concatenates then decompresses multiple resources to load an embedded .Net Framework assembly.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE can upload files from the victim's machine to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE has the capability to delete files and scripts from the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2. OopsIE also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE can download files from its C2 server to the victim's machine.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE creates and uses a VBScript as part of its persistent execution.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE uses the SmartAssembly obfuscator to pack an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE uses HTTP for C2 communications.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE checks to see if the system is configured with "Daylight" time and checks for a specific region to be set for the timezone.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: OopsIE uses WMI to perform discovery techniques.[2]

Orz.Name: Orz
Orz.Description: Orz is a custom JavaScript backdoor used by Leviathan. It was observed being used in 2014 as well as in August 2017 when it was dropped by Microsoft Publisher files. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can execute shell commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can gather victim drive information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can overwrite Registry settings to reduce its visibility on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Some Orz strings are base64 encoded, such as the embedded DLL known as MockDll.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can gather a process list from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Some Orz versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses process hollowing and Regsvr32 to execute another payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Some Orz versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses Process Hollowing and regsvr32 to execute another payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can download files onto the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can execute commands with script as well as execute JavaScript.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Orz can gather victim proxy information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Orz has used Technet and Pastebin web pages for command and control.[1]

OSInfo.Name: OSInfo
OSInfo.Description: OSInfo is a custom tool used by APT3 to do internal discovery on a victim's computer and network. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo enumerates local and domain users[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo discovers shares on the network[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo specifically looks for Domain Admins, Power Users, and the Administrators groups within the domain and locally[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo performs a connection test to discover remote systems in the network[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo discovers information about the infected machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo discovers the current domain information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OSInfo enumerates the current network connections similar to  net use .[1]

OwaAuth.Name: OwaAuth
OwaAuth.Description: OwaAuth is a Web shell and credential stealer deployed to Microsoft Exchange servers that appears to be exclusively used by Threat Group-3390. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth DES-encrypts captured credentials using the key 12345678 before writing the credentials to a log file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (DLL file). The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth has a command to list its directory and logical drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth captures and DES-encrypts credentials before writing the username and password to a log file, C:\log.txt.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth uses the filename owaauth.dll, which is a legitimate file that normally resides in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\Auth\; the malicious file by the same name is saved in %ProgramFiles%\Microsoft\Exchange Server\ClientAccess\Owa\bin\.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth uses incoming HTTP requests with a username keyword and commands and handles them as instructions to perform actions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth has a command to timestop a file or directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: OwaAuth is a Web shell that appears to be exclusively used by Threat Group-3390. It is installed as an ISAPI filter on Exchange servers and shares characteristics with the China Chopper Web shell.[1]

P2P ZeuS.Name: P2P ZeuS
P2P ZeuS.Description: P2P ZeuS is a closed-source fork of the leaked version of the ZeuS botnet. It presents improvements over the leaked version, including a peer-to-peer architecture. [1]
P2P ZeuS.Aliases: P2P ZeuS, Peer-to-Peer ZeuS, Gameover ZeuS

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: P2P ZeuS added junk data to outgoing UDP packets to peer implants.[1]

Pasam.Name: Pasam
Pasam.Description: Pasam is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam connects to external C2 infrastructure and opens a backdoor over port 443.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: LSASS Driver
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam establishes by infecting the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) DLL to load a malicious DLL dropped to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of running processes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pasam creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as hostname and free disk space.[2]

Pass-The-Hash Toolkit.Name: Pass-The-Hash Toolkit
Pass-The-Hash Toolkit.Description: Pass-The-Hash Toolkit is a toolkit that allows an adversary to "pass" a password hash (without knowing the original password) to log in to systems. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: Pass-The-Hash Toolkit can perform pass the hash.[1]

Pegasus for Android.Name: Pegasus for Android
Pegasus for Android.Description: Pegasus for Android is the Android version of malware that has reportedly been linked to the NSO Group. [1] [2] The iOS version is tracked separately under Pegasus for iOS.

Techniques Used.Name: Access Calendar Entries
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android accesses calendar entries.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android accesses call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android accesses contact list information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android accesses sensitive data in files, such as messages stored by the WhatsApp, Facebook, and Twitter applications. It also has the ability to access arbitrary filenames and retrieve directory listings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android uses SMS for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: App Auto-Start at Device Boot
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android listens for the BOOT_COMPLETED broadcast intent in order to maintain persistence and activate its functionality at device boot time.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android accesses the list of installed applications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android attempts to detect whether it is running in an emulator rather than a real device.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android attempts to exploit well-known Android OS vulnerabilities to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android checks if the device is on Wi-Fi, a cellular network, and is roaming.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android has the ability to record audio and take pictures using the device camera.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify System Partition
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for Android attempts to modify the device's system partition.[1]

Pegasus for iOS.Name: Pegasus for iOS
Pegasus for iOS.Description: Pegasus for iOS is the iOS version of malware that has reportedly been linked to the NSO Group. It has been advertised and sold to target high-value victims. [1] [2] The Android version is tracked separately under Pegasus for Android.

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS captures call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS gathers contacts from the system by dumping the victim's address book.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS accesses sensitive data in files, such as saving Skype calls by reading them out of the Skype database files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS uses SMS for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS captures SMS messages that the victim sends or receives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS was distributed through a web site by exploiting vulnerabilities in the Safari web browser on iOS devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS exploits iOS vulnerabilities to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit via Radio Interfaces
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS was delivered via an SMS message containing a link to a web site with malicious code.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS monitors the connection state and tracks which types of networks the phone is connected to, potentially to determine the bandwidth and ability to send full data across the network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS update and sends the location of the phone.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS has the ability to record audio.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify System Partition
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS modifies the system partition to maintain persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pegasus for iOS monitors the victim for status and disables other access to the phone by other jailbreaking software.[1]

PHOREAL.Name: PHOREAL
PHOREAL.Description: PHOREAL is a signature backdoor used by APT32. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: PHOREAL is capable of creating reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PHOREAL communicates via ICMP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PHOREAL is capable of manipulating the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PHOREAL communicates via ICMP for C2.[1]

PinchDuke.Name: PinchDuke
PinchDuke.Description: PinchDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2008 to 2010. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: PinchDuke steals credentials from compromised hosts. PinchDuke's credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch). Credentials targeted by PinchDuke include ones associated with The Bat!, Yahoo!, Mail.ru, Passport.Net, Google Talk, Netscape Navigator, Mozilla Firefox, Mozilla Thunderbird, Internet Explorer, Microsoft Outlook, WinInet Credential Cache, and Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: PinchDuke collects user files from the compromised host based on predefined file extensions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PinchDuke searches for files created within a certain timeframe and whose file extension matches a predefined list.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PinchDuke transfers files from the compromised host via HTTP or HTTPS to a C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PinchDuke gathers system configuration information.[1]

Ping.Name: Ping
Ping.Description: Ping is an operating system utility commonly used to troubleshoot and verify network connections. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ping can be used to identify remote systems within a network.[1]

Pisloader.Name: Pisloader
Pisloader.Description: Pisloader is a malware family that is notable due to its use of DNS as a C2 protocol as well as its use of anti-analysis tactics. It has been used by APT18 and is similar to another malware family, HTTPBrowser, that has been used by the group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader uses cmd.exe to set the Registry Run key value. It also has a command to spawn a command shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Responses from the Pisloader C2 server are base32-encoded.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used. The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader establishes persistence via a Registry Run key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader has a command to upload a file to the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader uses DNS as its C2 protocol.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pisloader has a command to collect the victim's IP address.[1]

PJApps.Name: PJApps
PJApps.Description: PJApps is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PJApps has the capability to collect and leak the victim's phone number, mobile device unique identifier (IMEI).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: PJApps has the capability to collect and leak the victim's location.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Premium SMS Toll Fraud
Techniques Used.Use: PJApps has the capability to send messages to premium SMS messages.[1]

PLAINTEE.Name: PLAINTEE
PLAINTEE.Description: PLAINTEE is a malware sample that has been used by Rancor in targeted attacks in Singapore and Cambodia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: An older variant of PLAINTEE performs UAC bypass.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE uses a custom UDP protocol to communicate.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE encodes C2 beacons using XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE uses reg add to add a Registry Run key for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE performs the tasklist command to list running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE gains persistence by adding the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE has downloaded and executed additional plugins.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PLAINTEE uses the ipconfig /all command to gather the victim’s IP address.[1]

PlugX.Name: PlugX
PlugX.Description: PlugX is a remote access tool (RAT) that uses modular plugins. [1] It has been used by multiple threat groups. [2] [3] [4]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX allows actors to spawn a reverse shell on a victim.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX has beaconed to its C2 over port 443.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX has used to use DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus and to maintain persistence on a victim.[2][4][6][5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can use the Windows API function CreateProcess to execute another process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: In one instance, menuPass added PlugX as a service with a display name of "Corel Writing Tools Utility."[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Multiband Communication
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can be configured to use multiple network protocols to avoid network-based detection.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can be added as a service to establish persistence.[1][5][8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can query for information contained within the Windows Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can add a Run key entry in the Registry to establish persistence.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can be configured to use HTTP or DNS for command and control.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Trusted Developer Utilities
Techniques Used.Use: A version of PlugX loads as shellcode within a .NET Framework project using msbuild.exe, presumably to bypass application whitelisting techniques.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: PlugX uses Pastebin to store its real C2 addresses.[7]

pngdowner.Name: pngdowner
pngdowner.Description:
pngdowner is malware used by Putter Panda. It is a simple tool with limited functionality and no persistence mechanism, suggesting it is used only as a simple "download-and-
execute" utility. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: If an initial connectivity check fails, pngdowner attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: pngdowner deletes content from C2 communications that was saved to the user's temporary directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: pngdowner uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

PoisonIvy.Name: PoisonIvy
PoisonIvy.Description: PoisonIvy is a popular remote access tool (RAT) that has been used by many groups. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy captures window titles.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command-line interface.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can steal system information.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy stages collected data in a text file.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy contains a keylogger.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a Registry entry modifying the Logical Disk Manager service to point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a Registry subkey that registers a new system device.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy can inject a malicious DLL into a process.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates run key Registry entries pointing to a malicious executable dropped to disk.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can upload files.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy starts a rootkit from a malicious file dropped to disk.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: PoisonIvy opens a backdoor on TCP ports 6868 and 7777.[3]

POORAIM.Name: POORAIM
POORAIM.Description: POORAIM is a backdoor used by APT37 in campaigns since at least 2014. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM can conduct file browsing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM can enumerate processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM can perform screen capturing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM can identify system information, including battery status.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: POORAIM has used AOL Instant Messenger for C2.[1]

POSHSPY.Name: POSHSPY
POSHSPY.Description: POSHSPY is a backdoor that has been used by APT29 since at least 2015. It appears to be used as a secondary backdoor used if the actors lost access to their primary backdoors. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY uploads data in 2048-byte chunks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY appends a file signature header (randomly selected from six file types) to encrypted data prior to upload or download.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY uses PowerShell to execute various commands, one to execute its payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY downloads and executes additional PowerShell code and Windows binaries.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY encrypts C2 traffic with AES and RSA.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY modifies timestamps of all downloaded executables to match a randomly selected file created prior to 2013.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Techniques Used.Use: POSHSPY uses a WMI event subscription to establish persistence.[1]

Power Loader.Name: Power Loader
Power Loader.Description: Power Loader is modular code sold in the cybercrime market used as a downloader in malware families such as Carberp, Redyms and Gapz. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Power Loader overwrites Explorer’s Shell_TrayWnd extra window memory to redirect execution to a NTDLL function that is abused to assemble and execute a return-oriented programming (ROP) chain and create a malicious thread within Explorer.exe.[1][2]

PowerDuke.Name: PowerDuke
PowerDuke.Description: PowerDuke is a backdoor that was used by APT29 in 2016. It has primarily been delivered through Microsoft Word or Excel attachments containing malicious macros. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has a command to get text of the current foreground window.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke runs cmd.exe /c and sends the output to its C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke connects over 443 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file. It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: NTFS File Attributes
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm (TEA).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has a command to list the victim's processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke achieves persistence by using various Registry Run keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has a command to download a file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke uses rundll32.exe to load.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has a command to get the victim's domain and NetBIOS name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has commands to get the current user's name and SID.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerDuke has commands to get the time the machine was built, the time, and the time zone.[1]

POWERSOURCE.Name: POWERSOURCE
POWERSOURCE.Description: POWERSOURCE is a PowerShell backdoor that is a heavily obfuscated and modified version of the publicly available tool DNS_TXT_Pwnage. It was observed in February 2017 in spearphishing campaigns against personnel involved with United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings at various organizations. The malware was delivered when macros were enabled by the victim and a VBS script was dropped. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: NTFS File Attributes
Techniques Used.Use: If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later, POWERSOURCE writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in %PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSOURCE is a PowerShell backdoor.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSOURCE queries Registry keys in preparation for setting Run keys to achieve persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSOURCE achieves persistence by setting a Registry Run key, with the path depending on whether the victim account has user or administrator access.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSOURCE has been observed being used to download TEXTMATE and the Cobalt Strike Beacon payload onto victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSOURCE uses DNS TXT records for C2.[1][2]

PowerSploit.Name: PowerSploit
PowerSploit.Description: PowerSploit is an open source, offensive security framework compromised of PowerShell modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Invoke-TokenManipulation Exfiltration module can be used to locate and impersonate user logon tokens.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Get-ProcessTokenGroup Privesc-PowerUp module can enumerate all SIDs associated with its current token.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Get-MicrophoneAudio Exfiltration module can record system microphone audio.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can harvest credentials from Group Policy Preferences, Windows vault credential objects, or using Mimikatz.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit has several modules that search the Windows Registry for stored credentials: Get-UnattendedInstallFile, Get-Webconfig, Get-ApplicationHost, Get-SiteListPassword, Get-CachedGPPPassword, and Get-RegistryAutoLogon.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can access data from local files, volumes, and processes.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit DLL hijacking opportunities in services and processes.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Find-AVSignature AntivirusBypass module can be used to locate single byte anti-virus signatures.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Get-Keystrokes Exfiltration module can log keystrokes.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Kerberoasting
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Invoke-Kerberoast module can request service tickets and return crackable ticket hashes.[5][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and replace/modify service binaries, paths, and configs.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of ScriptModification modules that compress and encode scripts and payloads.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Path Interception
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit various path interception opportunities in services, processes, and variables.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit modules are written in and executed via PowerShell.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Get-ProcessTokenPrivilege Privesc-PowerUp module can enumerate privileges for a given process.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of CodeExecution modules that enable by injecting code (DLL, shellcode) or reflectively loading a Windows PE file into a process.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can query Registry keys for potential opportunities.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's New-UserPersistenceOption Persistence argument can be used to establish via the HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run Registry key.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's New-UserPersistenceOption Persistence argument can be used to establish via a Scheduled Task.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Get-TimedScreenshot Exfiltration module can take screenshots at regular intervals.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Support Provider
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Install-SSP Persistence module can be used to establish by installing a SSP DLL.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: PowerSploit's Invoke-WmiCommand CodeExecution module uses WMI to execute and retrieve the output from a PowerShell payload.[1][3]

POWERSTATS.Name: POWERSTATS
POWERSTATS.Description: POWERSTATS is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by MuddyWater. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can retrieve usernames from compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS has used port 80 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS has connected to C2 servers through proxies.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS encoded C2 traffic with base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can upload files from compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can disable Microsoft Office Protected View by changing Registry keys.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Distributed Component Object Model
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can use DCOM (targeting the 127.0.0.1 loopback address) to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can use DDE to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can wipe drives using PowerShell Remove-Item commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Mshta
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can use Mshta.exe to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS uses character replacement, PowerShell environment variables, and XOR encoding to obfuscate code.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS uses PowerShell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can retrieve and execute additional PowerShell payloads from the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Transfer
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can sleep for a given number of seconds.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can retrieve screenshots from compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS has detected security tools.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS has encrypted C2 traffic with RSA.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can retrieve IP and network adapter configuration information from compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS has used ports 8060 and 8888 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: POWERSTATS can use WMI queries to retrieve data from compromised hosts.[2]

POWRUNER.Name: POWRUNER
POWRUNER.Description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect user account information by running net user /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER can execute commands from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER can use base64 encoded C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may enumerate user directories on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect permission group information by running net group /domain or a series of other commands on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER is written in PowerShell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect process information by running tasklist on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may query the Registry by running reg query on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER can download or upload files from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER persists through a scheduled task that executes it every minute.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER can capture a screenshot from a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect information the victim's anti-virus software.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER can use HTTP and DNS for C2 communications.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect information about the system by running hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect network configuration data by running ipconfig /all on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect active network connections by running netstat -an on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may collect information about the currently logged in user by running whoami on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: POWRUNER may use WMI when collecting information about a victim.[1]

Prikormka.Name: Prikormka
Prikormka.Description: Prikormka is a malware family used in a campaign known as Operation Groundbait. It has predominantly been observed in Ukraine and was used as early as 2008. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka gathers logins and passwords stored in applications on the victims, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and several other browsers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: After collecting documents from removable media, Prikormka compresses the collected files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka encodes C2 traffic with Base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: After collecting files and logs from the victim, Prikormka encrypts some collected data with Blowfish.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka contains a module that collects documents with certain extensions from removable media or fixed drives connected via USB.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka creates a directory, %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\SKC\, which is used to store collected log files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: After encrypting log files, the log encryption module in Prikormka deletes the original, unencrypted files from the host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka contains a keylogger module that collects keystrokes and the titles of foreground windows.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Some resources in Prikormka are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information on available printers and disk drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka adds itself to a Registry Run key with the name guidVGA or guidVSA.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka uses rundll32.exe to load its DLL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka contains a module that captures screenshots of the victim's desktop.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about installed anti-virus software.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Prikormka encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about its IP addresses and MAC addresses.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A module in Prikormka collects information from the victim about the current user name.[1]

Proton.Name: Proton
Proton.Description: Proton is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  [1].

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Proton gathers credentials in files for chrome, 1password, and keychains.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Proton zips up files before exfiltrating them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Proton uses an encrypted file to store commands and configuration values.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Proton kills security tools like Wireshark that are running.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Proton removes all files in the /tmp directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Proton removes logs from /var/logs and /Library/logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Proton uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Prompt
Techniques Used.Use: Proton prompts users for their credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Launch Agent
Techniques Used.Use: Proton persists via a Launch Agent.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Proton uses VNC to connect into systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Proton captures the content of the desktop with the screencapture binary.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Proton uses macOS' .command file type to script actions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Sudo Caching
Techniques Used.Use: Proton modifies the tty_tickets line in the sudoers file.[1]

Proxysvc.Name: Proxysvc
Proxysvc.Description: Proxysvc is a malicious DLL used by Lazarus Group in a campaign known as Operation GhostSecret. It has appeared to be operating undetected since 2017 and was mostly observed in higher education organizations. The goal of Proxysvc is to deliver additional payloads to the target and to maintain control for the attacker. It is in the form of a DLL that can also be executed as a standalone process. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc automatically collects data about the victim and sends it to the control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc executes a binary on the system and logs the results into a temp file by using: cmd.exe /c " > %temp%\PM* .tmp 2>&1".[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc uses port 443 for the control server communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc searches the local system and gathers data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc performs data exfiltration over the control server channel using a custom protocol.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc lists files in directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc can wipe files indicated by the attacker and remove itself from disk using a batch file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc lists processes running on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc gathers product names from the Registry key: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion ProductName and the processor description from the Registry key HKLM\HARDWARE\DESCRIPTION\System\CentralProcessor\0 ProcessorNameString.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc uses a batch file to delete itself.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc registers itself as a service on the victim’s machine to run as a standalone process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc uses HTTP over SSL to communicate commands with the control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Proxysvc collects the network adapter information and domain/username information based on current remote sessions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: As part of the data reconnaissance phase, Proxysvc grabs the system time to send back to the control server.[1]

PsExec.Name: PsExec
PsExec.Description: PsExec is a free Microsoft tool that can be used to execute a program on another computer. It is used by IT administrators and attackers. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Microsoft Sysinternals PsExec is a popular administration tool that can be used to execute binaries on remote systems using a temporary Windows service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: PsExec, a tool that has been used by adversaries, writes programs to the ADMIN$ network share to execute commands on remote systems.[3]

Psylo.Name: Psylo
Psylo.Description: Psylo is a shellcode-based Trojan that has been used by Scarlet Mimic. It has similar characteristics as FakeM. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Psylo exfiltrates data to its C2 server over the same protocol as C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Psylo has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Psylo has a command to download a file to the system from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Psylo uses HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Psylo has a command to conduct timestomping by setting a specified file’s timestamps to match those of a system file in the System32 directory.[1]

Pteranodon.Name: Pteranodon
Pteranodon.Description: Pteranodon is a custom backdoor used by Gamaredon Group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon can execute commands on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon creates various subdirectories under %Temp%\reports\% and copies files to those subdirectories. It also creates a folder at C:\Users\\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\store to store screenshot JPEG files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon exfiltrates screenshot files to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon identifies files matching certain file extension and copies them to subdirectories it created.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon can delete files that may interfere with it executing. It also can delete temporary files and itself after the initial script executes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon copies itself to the Startup folder to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon can download and execute additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon executes functions using rundll32.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon schedules tasks to invoke its components in order to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon can capture screenshots at a configurable interval.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Pteranodon can use HTTP for C2.[1]

PUNCHBUGGY.Name: PUNCHBUGGY
PUNCHBUGGY.Description: PUNCHBUGGY is a dynamic-link library (DLL) downloader utilized by FIN8. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: AppCert DLLs
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can establish using a AppCertDLLs Registry key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through Module Load
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can load a DLL using the LoadLibrary API.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can delete files written to disk.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY mimics filenames from %SYSTEM%\System32 to hide DLLs in %WINDIR% and/or %TEMP%.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can establish using a Registry run key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can download additional files and payloads to compromised hosts.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY can load a DLL using Rundll32.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHBUGGY enables remote interaction and can obtain additional code over HTTPS GET and POST requests.[1][2]

PUNCHTRACK.Name: PUNCHTRACK
PUNCHTRACK.Description: PUNCHTRACK is non-persistent point of sale (POS) system malware utilized by FIN8 to scrape payment card data. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHTRACK scrapes memory for properly formatted payment card data.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHTRACK aggregates collected data in a tmp file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: PUNCHTRACK is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.[1]

Pupy.Name: Pupy
Pupy.Description: Pupy is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. [1] It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). [1] Pupy is publicly available on GitHub. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can obtain a list of SIDs and provide the option for selecting process tokens to impersonate.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy uses PowerView and Pywerview to perform discovery commands such as net user, net group, net local group, etc.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can record sound with the microphone.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can bypass Windows UAC through either DLL hijacking, eventvwr, or appPaths.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can user PowerView to perform “net user” commands and create local system and domain accounts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy executes Mimikatz using PowerShell and can also perform pass-the-ticket and use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can compress data with Zip before sending it over C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can interact with a victim’s Outlook session and look through folders and emails.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can send screenshots files, keylogger data, files, and recorded audio back to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can walk through directories and recursively search for strings in files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy has a module to clear event logs with PowerShell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes it then sends back to the server after it is stopped.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can sniff plaintext network credentials and use NBNS Spoofing to poison name services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multilayer Encryption
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can use Obfs3, a pluggable transport, to add another layer of encryption and obfuscate TLS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy has a built-in module for port scanning.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can list local and remote shared drives and folders over SMB.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy has a module for loading and executing PowerShell scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can list the running processes and get the process ID and parent process’s ID.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can migrate into another process using reflective DLL injection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy adds itself to the startup folder or adds itself to the Registry key SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can enable/disable RDP connection and can start a remote desktop session using a browser web socket client.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can upload and download to/from a victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can drop a mouse-logger that will take small screenshots around at each click and then send back to the server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can use an add on feature when creating payloads that allows you to create custom Python scripts (“scriptlets”) to perform tasks offline (without requiring a session) such as sandbox detection, adding persistence, etc.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy uses PsExec to execute a payload or commands on a remote host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can communicate over HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy's default encryption for its C2 communication channel is SSL, but it also has transport options for RSA and AES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy has built in commands to identify a host’s IP address and find out other network configuration settings by viewing connected sessions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy has a built-in utility command for netstat, can do net session through PowerView, and has an interactive shell which can be used to discover additional information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can enumerate local information for Linux hosts and find currently logged on users for Windows hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Pupy can access a connected webcam and capture pictures.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: pwdump can be used to dump credentials.[1]

QUADAGENT.Name: QUADAGENT
QUADAGENT.Description: QUADAGENT is a PowerShell backdoor used by OilRig. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses cmd.exe to execute scripts and commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT encodes C2 communications with base64.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses AES and a preshared key to decrypt the custom Base64 routine used to encode strings and scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses multiple protocols (HTTPS, HTTP, DNS) for its C2 server as fallback channels if communication with one is unsuccessful.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT has a command to delete its Registry key and scheduled task.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT used the PowerShell filenames Office365DCOMCheck.ps1 and SystemDiskClean.ps1.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT modifies an HKCU Registry key to store a session identifier unique to the compromised system as well as a pre-shared key used for encrypting and decrypting C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT was likely obfuscated using Invoke-Obfuscation.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses PowerShell scripts for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT checks if a value exists within a Registry key in the HKCU hive whose name is the same as the scheduled task it has created.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses VBScripts and batch scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT uses HTTPS, HTTP, and DNS for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT gathers the current domain the victim system belongs to.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: QUADAGENT gathers the victim username.[1]

QuasarRAT.Name: QuasarRAT
QuasarRAT.Description: QuasarRAT is an open-source, remote access tool that is publicly available on GitHub. QuasarRAT is developed in the C# language. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: A QuasarRAT .dll file is digitally signed by a certificate from AirVPN.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can launch a remote shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can communicate over a reverse proxy using SOCKS5.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can obtain passwords from common browsers and FTP clients.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can obtain passwords from common browsers and FTP clients.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT has a built-in keylogger.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT has dropped binaries as files named microsoft_network.exe and crome.exe.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT has a command to edit the Registry on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT has a module for performing remote desktop access.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can download files to the victim’s machine and execute them.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT contains a .NET wrapper DLL for creating and managing scheduled tasks for maintaining persistence upon reboot.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT uses AES to encrypt network communication.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT has a command to gather system information from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: QuasarRAT can perform webcam viewing.[1][2]

RARSTONE.Name: RARSTONE
RARSTONE.Description: RARSTONE is malware used by the Naikon group that has some characteristics similar to PlugX. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
