Techniques Used.Use: RARSTONE obtains installer properties from Uninstall Registry Key entries to obtain information about installed applications and how to uninstall certain applications.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: After decrypting itself in memory, RARSTONE downloads a DLL file from its C2 server and loads it in the memory space of a hidden Internet Explorer process. This “downloaded” file is actually not dropped onto the system.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RARSTONE downloads its backdoor component from a C2 server and loads it directly into memory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RARSTONE uses SSL to encrypt its communication with its C2 server.[1]

RATANKBA.Name: RATANKBA
RATANKBA.Description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group. RATANKBA has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. RATANKBA has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses the net user command.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses cmd.exe to execute commands.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses port 443 for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: There is a variant of RATANKBA that uses a PowerShell script instead of the traditional PE form.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA lists the system’s processes.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses the command reg query “HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings”.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uploads and downloads information.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA runs the net view /domain and net view commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses HTTP/HTTPS for command and control communication.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA gathers the victim’s IP address via the ipconfig -all command.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses netstat -ano to search for specific IP address ranges.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA runs the whoami and query user commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses tasklist /svc to display running tasks.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: RATANKBA uses WMI to perform process monitoring.[1][2]

RawPOS.Name: RawPOS
RawPOS.Description: RawPOS is a point-of-sale (POS) malware family that searches for cardholder data on victims. It has been in use since at least 2008. [1] [2] [3] FireEye divides RawPOS into three components: FIENDCRY, DUEBREW, and DRIFTWOOD. [4] [5]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: RawPOS encodes credit card data it collected from the victim with XOR.[2][4][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: RawPOS dumps memory from specific processes on a victim system, parses the dumped files, and scrapes them for credit card data.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Data captured by RawPOS is placed in a temporary file under a directory named "memdump".[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: New services created by RawPOS are made to appear like legitimate Windows services, with names such as "Windows Management Help Service", "Microsoft Support", and "Windows Advanced Task Manager".[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: RawPOS installs itself as a service to maintain persistence.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can collect passwords for Wi-Fi networks and online accounts, including Skype, Facebook, Twitter, Google, WhatsApp, Mail, and LinkedIn.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can use SMS for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can monitor clipboard content.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can collect SMS, MMS, and Gmail messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid has the ability to dynamically download and execute new code at runtime.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can record location.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: RCSAndroid can record using the microphone as well as capture photos using the front and back cameras.[1]

Reaver.Name: Reaver
Reaver.Description: Reaver is a malware family that has been in the wild since at least late 2016. Reporting indicates victims have primarily been associated with the "Five Poisons," which are movements the Chinese government considers dangerous. The type of malware is rare due to its final payload being in the form of Control Panel Items. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Control Panel Items
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver drops and executes a malicious CPL file as its payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Reaver variants use raw TCP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver encrypts collected data with an incremental XOR key prior to exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver deletes the original dropped file from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver installs itself as a new service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver encrypts some of its files with XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver queries the Registry to determine the correct Startup path to use for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Reaver variants use HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Reaver variants use raw TCP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver collects the victim's IP address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Reaver collects the victim's username.[1]

RedDrop.Name: RedDrop
RedDrop.Description: RedDrop is an Android malware family that exfiltrates sensitive data from devices. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop uses ads or other links within web sites to encourage users to download the malicious apps. A complex content distribution network (CDN) and series of network redirects is used in an apparent attempt to evade malware detection techniques.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Device Type Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop exfiltrates details of the victim device operating system and manufacturer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop downloads additional components (APKs, JAR files) from different C&C servers and stores them dynamically into the device’s memory, allowing the adversary to execute additional malicious APKs without having to embed them straight into the initial sample.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop exfiltrates IMEI, IMSI, MNC, MCC, nearby WiFi networks, and other device and SIM related info.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop exfiltrates locally saved files (including photos) as well as live recordings of the device's surroundings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop contains malicious embedded files, which are compiled to initiate the malicious functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Premium SMS Toll Fraud
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop tricks the user into sending SMS messages to premium services and then deletes those messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RedDrop exfiltrates data using standard HTTP.[1]

RedLeaves.Name: RedLeaves
RedLeaves.Description: RedLeaves is a malware family used by menuPass. The code overlaps with PlugX and may be based upon the open source tool Trochilus. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can receive and execute commands with cmd.exe. It can also provide a reverse shell.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves uses a specific port of 443 and can also use ports 53 and 80 for C2. One RedLeaves variant uses HTTP over port 443 to connect to its C2 server.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can gather browser usernames and passwords.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over TCP using a custom binary protocol.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can enumerate and search for files and directories.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can delete specified files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A RedLeaves configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence. If this fails, it attempts to add Registry Run keys.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves is capable of downloading a file from a specified URL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can capture screenshots.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can communicate to its C2 over HTTP and HTTPS if directed.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can obtain information about network parameters.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can enumerate drives and Remote Desktop sessions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can obtain information about the logged on user both locally and for Remote Desktop sessions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: RedLeaves can use port 995 for C2.[1]

Reg.Name: Reg
Reg.Description:
Reg is a Windows utility used to interact with the Windows Registry. It can be used at the command-line interface to query, add, modify, and remove information. [1]
Utilities such as Reg are known to be used by persistent threats. [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Reg may be used to find credentials in the Windows Registry.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Reg may be used to interact with and modify the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Reg may be used to gather details from the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.[1]

Regin.Name: Regin
Regin.Description: Regin is a malware platform that has targeted victims in a range of industries, including telecom, government, and financial institutions. Some Regin timestamps date back to 2003. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Regin stage 1 modules for 64-bit systems have been found to be signed with fake certificates masquerading as originating from Microsoft Corporation and Broadcom Corporation.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Regin leveraged several compromised universities as proxies to obscure its origin.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Regin malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Regin contains a keylogger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Regin appears to have functionality to modify remote Registry information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Sniffing
Techniques Used.Use: Regin appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: NTFS File Attributes
Techniques Used.Use: The Regin malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Regin malware platform supports many standard protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, and SMB.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Regin malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: The Regin malware platform can use Windows admin shares to move laterally.[1]

RemoteCMD.Name: RemoteCMD
RemoteCMD.Description: RemoteCMD is a custom tool used by APT3 to execute commands on a remote system similar to SysInternal's PSEXEC functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RemoteCMD copies a file over to the remote system before execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: RemoteCMD can execute commands remotely by creating a new schedule task on the remote system[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: RemoteCMD can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.[1]

Remsec.Name: Remsec
Remsec.Description: Remsec is a modular backdoor that has been used by Strider and appears to have been designed primarily for espionage purposes. Many of its modules are written in Lua. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain a list of users.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can dump the SAM database.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec has a package that collects documents from any inserted USB sticks.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can add or remove applications or ports on the Windows firewall or disable it entirely.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can exfiltrate data via a DNS tunnel or email, separately from its C2 channel.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec contains a module to move data from airgapped networks to Internet-connected systems by using a removable USB device.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec has a plugin to drop and execute vulnerable Outpost Sandbox or avast! Virtualization drivers in order to gain kernel mode privileges.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim. Remsec also searches for custom network encryption software on victims.[3][4][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec is capable of deleting files on the victim. It also securely removes itself after collecting and exfiltrating data.[3][4][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec contains a keylogger component.[3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: The Remsec loader implements itself with the name Security Support Provider, a legitimate Windows function. Various Remsec .exe files mimic legitimate file names used by Microsoft, Symantec, Kaspersky, Hewlett-Packard, and VMWare. Remsec also disguised malicious modules using similar filenames as custom network encryption software on victims.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec has a plugin that can perform ARP scanning as well as port scanning.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Some data in Remsec is encrypted using RC5 in CBC mode, AES-CBC with a hardcoded key, RC4, or Salsa20. Some data is also base64-encoded.[3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Password Filter DLL
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec harvests plain-text credentials as a password filter registered on domain controllers.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain a process list from the victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can perform DLL injection.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec contains a network loader to receive executable modules from remote attackers and run them on the local victim. It can also upload and download files over HTTP and HTTPS.[3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can ping or traceroute a remote host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec schedules the execution one of its modules by creating a new scheduler task.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec is capable of using HTTP, HTTPS, SMTP, and DNS for C2.[3][4][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec's network loader encrypts C2 traffic with RSA and RC6.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain information about network configuration, including the routing table, ARP cache, and DNS cache.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain a list of active connections and open ports.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Remsec can obtain information about the current user.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: A Remsec module has a default C2 port of 13000.[2]

Responder.Name: Responder
Responder.Description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning
Techniques Used.Use: Responder is used to poison name services to gather hashes and credentials from systems within a local network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Sniffing
Techniques Used.Use: Responder captures hashes and credentials that are sent to the system after the name services have been poisoned.[1]

RGDoor.Name: RGDoor
RGDoor.Description: RGDoor is a malicious Internet Information Services (IIS) backdoor developed in the C++ language. RGDoor has been seen deployed on webservers belonging to the Middle East government organizations. RGDoor provides backdoor access to compromised IIS servers. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor encrypts files with XOR before sending them back to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor decodes Base64 strings and decrypts strings using a custom XOR algorithm.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor uploads and downloads files to and from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor uses HTTP for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RGDoor executes the whoami on the victim’s machine.[1]

RIPTIDE.Name: RIPTIDE
RIPTIDE.Description: RIPTIDE is a proxy-aware backdoor used by APT12. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: RIPTIDE is a RAT that communicates with HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT12 has used RIPTIDE, a RAT that uses HTTP to communicate.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT12 has used the RIPTIDE RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.[1]

ROCKBOOT.Name: ROCKBOOT
ROCKBOOT.Description: ROCKBOOT is a Bootkit that has been used by an unidentified, suspected China-based group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bootkit
Techniques Used.Use: ROCKBOOT is a Master Boot Record (MBR) bootkit that uses the MBR to establish persistence.[1]

RogueRobin.Name: RogueRobin
RogueRobin.Description: RogueRobin is a custom PowerShell-based payload used by DarkHydrus. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin uses a command prompt to run a PowerShell script from Excel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin uses a custom DNS tunneling protocol for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin base64 encodes strings that are sent to the C2 over its DNS tunnel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: The PowerShell script with the RogueRobin payload was obfuscated using the COMPRESS technique in Invoke-Obfuscation.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin uses PowerShell for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin checks the running processes for evidence it may be running in a sandbox environment. It specifically enumerates processes for Wireshark and Sysinternals.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin created a shortcut in the Windows startup folder to launch a PowerShell script each time the user logs in to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin can download files from the C2 server to the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin has a command named $screenshot that may be responsible for taking screenshots of the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: To assist in establishing persistence, RogueRobin creates %APPDATA%\OneDrive.bat and saves the following string to it:powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -exec bypass -File “%APPDATA%\OneDrive.ps1”.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin enumerates running processes to search for Wireshark and Windows Sysinternals suite.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin establishes persistence by creating a shortcut in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin gathers BIOS versions and manufacturers, the number of CPU cores, the total physical memory, and the computer name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin gathers the IP address and domain from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin collects the victim’s username and whether that user is an admin.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: RogueRobin uses various WMI queries to check if the sample is running in a sandbox.[1]

ROKRAT.Name: ROKRAT
ROKRAT.Description: ROKRAT is a remote access tool (RAT) used by APT37. This software has been used to target victims in South Korea. APT37 used ROKRAT during several campaigns in 2016 through 2018. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT steals credentials stored in Web browsers by querying the sqlite database and leveraging the Windows Vault mechanism.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT sends collected files back over same C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT uses a keylogger to capture keystrokes and location of where the user is typing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT lists the current running processes on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT accesses the HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\mssmbios\Data\SMBiosData Registry key to obtain the System manufacturer value to identify the machine type.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT retrieves additional malicious payloads from the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT captures screenshots of the infected system.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT checks for sandboxing libraries and debugging tools.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT use HTTPS for all command and control communication methods.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT gathers the computer name and checks the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: ROKRAT leverages legitimate social networking sites and cloud platforms (Twitter, Yandex, and Mediafire) for command and control communications.[1]

route.Name: route
route.Description: route can be used to find or change information within the local system IP routing table. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: route can be used to discover routing configuration information.

Rover.Name: Rover
Rover.Description: Rover is malware suspected of being used for espionage purposes. It was used in 2015 in a targeted email sent to an Indian Ambassador to Afghanistan. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Rover automatically collects files from the local system and removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions on a regular timeframe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Exfiltration
Techniques Used.Use: Rover automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions and sends them to the command and control server every 60 minutes. Rover also automatically sends keylogger files and screenshots to the C2 server on a regular timeframe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Rover searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Rover searches for files on attached removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions every five seconds.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Rover copies files from removable drives to C:\system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Rover automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Rover has keylogging functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Rover has functionality to remove Registry Run key persistence as a cleanup procedure.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Rover persists by creating a Registry entry in HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Rover takes screenshots of the compromised system's desktop and saves them to C:\system\screenshot.bmp for exfiltration every 60 minutes.[1]

RTM.Name: RTM
RTM.Description: RTM is custom malware written in Delphi. It is used by the group of the same name (RTM). [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: RTM monitors browsing activity and automatically captures screenshots if a victim browses to a URL matching one of a list of strings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can attempt to run the program as admin, then show a fake error message and a legitimate UAC bypass prompt to the user in an attempt to socially engineer the user into escalating privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: RTM collects data from the clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: RTM samples have been signed with a code-signing certificates.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: RTM uses the command line and rundll32.exe to execute.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RTM uses HTTP POST requests with data formatted using a custom protocol.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RTM encrypts C2 traffic with a custom RC4 variant.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can scan victim drives to look for specific banking software on the machine to determine next actions. It also looks at browsing history and open tabs for specific strings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can delete all files created during its execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: RTM has the ability to remove Registry entries that it created during execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can record keystrokes from both the keyboard and virtual keyboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Install Root Certificate
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can add a certificate to the Windows store.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can delete all Registry entries created during its execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: RTM strings, network data, configuration, and modules are encrypted with a modified RC4 algorithm.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain a list of smart card readers attached to the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain information about process integrity levels.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: RTM tries to add a Registry Run key under the name "Windows Update" to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can download additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: RTM runs its core DLL file using rundll32.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: RTM tries to add a scheduled task to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can capture screenshots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain information about security software on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain the computer name, OS version, and default language identifier.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain the victim username and permissions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RTM can obtain the victim time zone.[1]

RuMMS.Name: RuMMS
RuMMS.Description: RuMMS is an Android malware family. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: RuMMS uploads incoming SMS messages to a remote command and control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: RuMMS is delivered via an SMS message containing a link to an APK (Android application package).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RuMMS gathers the device phone number and IMEI and transmits them to a command and control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: RuMMS uses HTTP for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RuMMS gathers device model and operating system version information and transmits it to a command and control server.[1]

RunningRAT.Name: RunningRAT
RunningRAT.Description: RunningRAT is a remote access tool that appeared in operations surrounding the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics along with Gold Dragon and Brave Prince. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT contains code to open and copy data from the clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT contains code to compress files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT kills antimalware running process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT contains code to delete files from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT contains code to clear event logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT captures keystrokes and sends them back to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT adds itself to the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence upon reboot.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT uses a batch file to kill a security program task and then attempts to remove itself.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: RunningRAT gathers the OS version, logical drives information, processor information, and volume information.[1]

S-Type.Name: S-Type
S-Type.Description: S-Type is a backdoor that was used by Dust Storm from 2013 to 2014. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type runs the command net user on a victim. S-Type also runs tests to determine the privilege level of the compromised user.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type uses ports 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type may create a temporary user on the system named “Lost_{Unique Identifier}” with the password “pond~!@6”{Unique Identifier}.”[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type uses Base64 encoding for C2 traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type may save itself as a file named msdtc.exe, which is also the name of the legitimate Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type may create a .lnk file to itself that is saved in the Start menu folder. It may also create the Registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ IMJPMIJ8.1{3 characters of Unique Identifier}.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type may create the file %HOMEPATH%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Realtek {Unique Identifier}.lnk, which points to the malicious msdtc.exe file already created in the %CommonFiles% directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: The initial beacon packet for S-Type contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: S-Type runs the command net start on a victim.[1]

Sakula.Name: Sakula
Sakula.Description: Sakula is a remote access tool (RAT) that first surfaced in 2012 and was used in intrusions throughout 2015. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula contains UAC bypass code for both 32- and 64-bit systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32 and also to perform file cleanup. Sakula also has the capability to invoke a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Some Sakula samples use cmd.exe to delete temporary files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Some Sakula samples install themselves as services for persistence by calling WinExec with the net start argument.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Most Sakula samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula has the capability to download files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula calls cmd.exe to run various DLL files via rundll32.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Sakula uses HTTP for C2.[1]

schtasks.Name: schtasks
schtasks.Description: schtasks is used to schedule execution of programs or scripts on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: schtasks is used to schedule tasks on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time.[1]

SDelete.Name: SDelete
SDelete.Description: SDelete is an application that securely deletes data in a way that makes it unrecoverable. It is part of the Microsoft Sysinternals suite of tools. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: SDelete is digitally signed by Microsoft.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: SDelete deletes data in a way that makes it unrecoverable.[1]

SeaDuke.Name: SeaDuke
SeaDuke.Description: SeaDuke is malware that was used by APT29 from 2014 to 2015. It was used primarily as a secondary backdoor for victims that were already compromised with CozyCar. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke is capable of executing commands.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke compressed data with zlib prior to sending it over C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke C2 traffic is base64-encoded.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Some SeaDuke samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke can securely delete files, including deleting itself from the victim.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Ticket
Techniques Used.Use: Some SeaDuke samples have a module to use pass the ticket with Kerberos for authentication.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke is capable of persisting via the Registry Run key or a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke is capable of uploading and downloading files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke uses a module to execute Mimikatz with PowerShell to perform Pass the Ticket.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke is capable of persisting via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke has been packed with the UPX packer.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke uses HTTP and HTTPS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke C2 traffic has been encrypted with RC4 and AES.[3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Some SeaDuke samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Techniques Used.Use: SeaDuke uses an event filter in WMI code to execute a previously dropped executable shortly after system startup.[5]

SEASHARPEE.Name: SEASHARPEE
SEASHARPEE.Description: SEASHARPEE is a Web shell that has been used by APT34. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: SEASHARPEE can execute commands on victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: SEASHARPEE can download remote files onto victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: SEASHARPEE can timestomp files on victims using a Web shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: SEASHARPEE is a Web shell.[1]

Shamoon.Name: Shamoon
Shamoon.Description: Shamoon is malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. The 2.0 version was seen in 2016 targeting Middle Eastern states. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon attempts to disable UAC remote restrictions by modifying the Registry.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon has used TCP port 8080 for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon attempts to access the ADMIN$, C$\Windows, D$\Windows, and E$\Windows shares on the victim with its current privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon attempts to overwrite operating system files with image files.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon creates a new service named “ntssrv” that attempts to appear legitimate; the service's display name is “Microsoft Network Realtime Inspection Service” and its description is “Helps guard against time change attempts targeting known and newly discovered vulnerabilities in network time protocols.”[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Once Shamoon has access to a network share, it enables the RemoteRegistry service on the target system. It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy to 1.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon contains base64-encoded strings.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon queries several Registry keys to identify hard disk partitions to overwrite.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon can download an executable to run on the victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon scans the C-class subnet of the IPs on the victim's interfaces.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon copies an executable payload to the target system by using Windows Admin Shares and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon uses HTTP for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon obtains the target's IP address and local network segment.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon obtains the system time and will only activate if it is greater than a preset date.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: If Shamoon cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Shamoon accesses network share(s), enables share access to the target device, and copies an executable payload to the target system, and uses a Scheduled Task to execute the malware.[1]

ShiftyBug.Name: ShiftyBug
ShiftyBug.Description: ShiftyBug is an auto-rooting adware family of malware for Android. The family is very similar to the other Android families known as Shedun, Shuanet, Kemoge, though it is not believed all the families were created by the same group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: ShiftyBug is packed with at least eight publicly available exploits that can perform rooting.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify System Partition
Techniques Used.Use: ShiftyBug is auto-rooting adware that embeds itself as a system application, making it nearly impossible to remove.[1]

SHIPSHAPE.Name: SHIPSHAPE
SHIPSHAPE.Description: SHIPSHAPE is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: SHIPSHAPE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: APT30 may have used the SHIPSHAPE malware to move onto air-gapped networks. SHIPSHAPE targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: SHIPSHAPE achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.[1]

SHOTPUT.Name: SHOTPUT
SHOTPUT.Description: SHOTPUT is a custom backdoor used by APT3. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT has a command to retrieve information about connected users.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT has a command to obtain a directory listing.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT has a command to obtain a process listing.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT has a command to list all servers in the domain, as well as one to locate domain controllers on a domain.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHOTPUT uses netstat to list TCP connection status.[2]

SHUTTERSPEED.Name: SHUTTERSPEED
SHUTTERSPEED.Description: SHUTTERSPEED is a backdoor used by APT37. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: SHUTTERSPEED can download and execute an arbitary executable.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: SHUTTERSPEED can capture screenshots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SHUTTERSPEED can collect system information.[1]

Skeleton Key.Name: Skeleton Key
Skeleton Key.Description: Skeleton Key is malware used to inject false credentials into domain controllers with the intent of creating a backdoor password. [1] Functionality similar to Skeleton Key is included as a module in Mimikatz.

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Skeleton Key is used to patch an enterprise domain controller authentication process with a backdoor password. It allows adversaries to bypass the standard authentication system to use a defined password for all accounts authenticating to that domain controller.[1]

Skygofree.Name: Skygofree
Skygofree.Description: Skygofree is Android spyware that is believed to have been developed in 2014 and used through at least 2017. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree has a capability to obtain files from other installed applications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree can be controlled via binary SMS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree can download executable code from the C2 server after the implant starts or after a specific command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree has the capability to exploit several known vulnerabilities and escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree can record audio via the microphone when an infected device is in a specified location as well as record a video or capture a photo.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Skygofree can be controlled via HTTP, XMPP, FirebaseCloudMessaging, or GoogleCloudMessaging in older versions.[1]

SLOWDRIFT.Name: SLOWDRIFT
SLOWDRIFT.Description: SLOWDRIFT is a backdoor used by APT37 against academic and strategic victims in South Korea. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: SLOWDRIFT downloads additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SLOWDRIFT collects and sends system information to its C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: SLOWDRIFT uses cloud based services for C2.[1]

Smoke Loader.Name: Smoke Loader
Smoke Loader.Description:
Smoke Loader is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
Smoke Loader has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for its use of deception and self-protection. It also comes with several plug-ins. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials and also looks for credentials stored from browsers.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader deobfuscates its code.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader searches through Outlook files and directories (e.g., inbox, sent, templates, drafts, archives, etc.).[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader recursively searches through directories for files.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader spawns a new copy of c:\windows\syswow64\explorer.exe and then replaces the executable code in memory with malware.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader injects into the Internet Explorer process.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader adds a Registry Run key for persistence and adds a script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader downloads a new version of itself once it has installed. It also downloads additional plugins.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader launches a scheduled task.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader adds a Visual Basic script in the Startup folder to deploy the payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Smoke Loader was distributed through a compromised update to a Tor client with a coin miner payload.[2]

SNUGRIDE.Name: SNUGRIDE
SNUGRIDE.Description: SNUGRIDE is a backdoor that has been used by menuPass as first stage malware. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: SNUGRIDE is capable of executing commands and spawning a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: SNUGRIDE establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: SNUGRIDE communicates with its C2 server over HTTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: SNUGRIDE encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.[1]

Socksbot.Name: Socksbot
Socksbot.Description: Socksbot is a backdoor that  abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Socksbot can start SOCKS proxy threads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Socksbot can write and execute PowerShell scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Socksbot can list all running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Socksbot creates a suspended svchost process and injects its DLL into it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Socksbot can take screenshots.[1]

SOUNDBITE.Name: SOUNDBITE
SOUNDBITE.Description: SOUNDBITE is a signature backdoor used by APT32. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SOUNDBITE is capable of enumerating application windows.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SOUNDBITE is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: SOUNDBITE is capable of modifying the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: SOUNDBITE communicates via DNS for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SOUNDBITE is capable of gathering system information.[1]

SPACESHIP.Name: SPACESHIP
SPACESHIP.Description: SPACESHIP is malware developed by APT30 that allows propagation and exfiltration of data over removable devices. APT30 may use this capability to exfiltrate data across air-gaps. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Data SPACESHIP copies to the staging area is compressed with zlib. Bytes are rotated by four positions and XOR'ed with 0x23.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: SPACESHIP identifies files with certain extensions and copies them to a directory in the user's profile.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Techniques Used.Use: SPACESHIP copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SPACESHIP identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: SPACESHIP achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: SPACESHIP achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.[1]

spwebmember.Name: spwebmember
spwebmember.Description: spwebmember is a Microsoft SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool written in .NET. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Information Repositories
Techniques Used.Use: spwebmember is used to enumerate and dump information from Microsoft SharePoint.[1]

SpyDealer.Name: SpyDealer
SpyDealer.Description: SpyDealer is Android malware that exfiltrates sensitive data from Android devices. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Abuse Accessibility Features
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer abuses Android Accessibility features to steal messages from popular apps such as WeChat, Skype, Viber, and QQ.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer harvests phone call history from victims..[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer harvests contact lists from victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer exfiltrates data from over 40 apps such as WeChat, Facebook, WhatsApp, Skype, and others.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer enables remote control of the victim through SMS channels.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: App Auto-Start at Device Boot
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer registers the broadcast receiver to listen for events related to device boot-up.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer harvests SMS and MMS messages from victims..[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer downloads and executes root exploits from a remote server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit OS Vulnerability
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer uses the commercial rooting app Baidu Easy Root to gain root privilege and maintain persistence on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer harvests phone number IMEI, and IMSI.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer harvests location data from victims..[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer can record phone calls and surrounding audio and video, as well as take photos via front and rear cameras.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify System Partition
Techniques Used.Use: SpyDealer maintains persistence by installing an Android application package (APK) on the system partition.[1]

SpyNote RAT.Name: SpyNote RAT
SpyNote RAT.Description: SpyNote RAT (Remote Access Trojan) is a family of malicious Android apps. The SpyNote RAT builder tool can be used to develop malicious apps with the malware's functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT can view contacts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT can copy files from the device to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: App Auto-Start at Device Boot
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT uses an Android broadcast receiver to automatically start when the device boots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT can read SMS messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT collects the device's location.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: SpyNote RAT can activate the victim's microphone.[1]

sqlmap.Name: sqlmap
sqlmap.Description: sqlmap is an open source penetration testing tool that can be used to automate the process of detecting and exploiting SQL injection flaws. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Techniques Used.Use: sqlmap can be used to automate exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities.[1]

SslMM.Name: SslMM
SslMM.Description: SslMM is a full-featured backdoor used by Naikon that has multiple variants. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM contains a feature to manipulate process privileges and tokens.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM identifies and kills anti-malware processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM has a hard-coded primary and backup C2 string.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM creates a new thread implementing a keylogging facility using Windows Keyboard Accelerators.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: To establish persistence, SslMM identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: To establish persistence, SslMM identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: To establish persistence, SslMM identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SslMM sends the logged-on username to its hard-coded C2.[1]

Starloader.Name: Starloader
Starloader.Description: Starloader is a loader component that has been observed loading Felismus and associated tools. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Starloader decrypts and executes shellcode from a file called Stars.jps.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Starloader has masqueraded as legitimate software update packages such as Adobe Acrobat Reader and Intel.[1]

Stealth Mango.Name: Stealth Mango
Stealth Mango.Description: Stealth Mango is Android malware that has reportedly been used to successfully compromise the mobile devices of government officials, members of the military, medical professionals, and civilians. The iOS malware known as Tangelo is believed to be from the same developer. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Calendar Entries
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads calendar events and reminders.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Contact List
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads contact lists for various third-party applications such as Yahoo, AIM, GoogleTalk, Skype, QQ, and others.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango exfiltrated data, including sensitive letters/documents, stored photos, and stored audio files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Alternate Network Mediums
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uses commands received from text messages for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads information about installed packages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads SMS logs and deletes incoming messages from specified numbers, including those that contain particular strings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango is delivered via a a watering hole website that mimics the third-party Android app store APKMonk. In at least one case, the watering hole URL was distributed through Facebook Messenger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango uploads information about changes in SIM card or phone numbers on the device.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango can perform GPS location tracking as well as capturing coordinates as when an SMS message or call is received.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango can record from the camera or microphone as well as take photos from the front and back cameras.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Mango in at least one case may have been installed using physical access to the device by a repair shop.[1]

StreamEx.Name: StreamEx
StreamEx.Description: StreamEx is a malware family that has been used by Deep Panda since at least 2015. In 2016, it was distributed via legitimate compromised Korean websites. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to remotely execute commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to enumerate drive types.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to modify the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx establishes persistence by installing a new service pointing to its DLL and setting the service to auto-start.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx obfuscates some commands by using statically programmed fragments of strings when starting a DLL. It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to enumerate processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx uses rundll32 to call an exported function.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to scan for security tools such as firewalls and antivirus tools.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: StreamEx has the ability to enumerate system information.[1]

Sykipot.Name: Sykipot
Sykipot.Description: Sykipot is malware that has been used in spearphishing campaigns since approximately 2007 against victims primarily in the US. One variant of Sykipot hijacks smart cards on victims. [1] The group using this malware has also been referred to as Sykipot. [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may use net group "domain admins" /domain to display accounts in the "domain admins" permissions group and net localgroup "administrators" to list local system administrator group membership.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot contains keylogging functionality to steal passwords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multilayer Encryption
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot communicates using HTTPS and uses a custom encryption cipher to encrypt the HTTPS message body.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may gather a list of running processes by running tasklist /v.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may use net view /domain to display hostnames of available systems on a network.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may use ipconfig /all to gather system network configuration details.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may use netstat -ano to display active network connections.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot may use net start to display running services.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Two-Factor Authentication Interception
Techniques Used.Use: Sykipot is known to contain functionality that enables targeting of smart card technologies to proxy authentication for connections to restricted network resources using detected hardware tokens.[1]

SynAck.Name: SynAck
SynAck.Description: SynAck is variant of Trojan ransomware targeting mainly English-speaking users since at least fall 2017. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck parses the export tables of system DLLs to locate and call various Windows API functions.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck clears event logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck can manipulate Registry keys.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck payloads are obfuscated prior to compilation to inhibit analysis and/or reverse engineering.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck enumerates all running processes.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Doppelgänging
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck abuses NTFS transactions to launch and conceal malicious processes.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck enumerates Registry keys associated with event logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck gathers computer names, OS version info, and also checks installed keyboard layouts to estimate if it has been launched from a certain list of countries.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck gathers user names from infected hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: SynAck enumerates all running services.[1][2]

Sys10.Name: Sys10
Sys10.Description: Sys10 is a backdoor that was used throughout 2013 by Naikon. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 collects the group name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 collects the local IP address of the victim and sends it to the C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sys10 collects the account name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.[1]

Systeminfo.Name: Systeminfo
Systeminfo.Description: Systeminfo is a Windows utility that can be used to gather detailed information about a computer. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Systeminfo can be used to gather information about the operating system.[1]

T9000.Name: T9000
T9000.Description: T9000 is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: AppInit DLLs
Techniques Used.Use: If a victim meets certain criteria, T9000 uses the AppInit_DLL functionality to achieve persistence by ensuring that every user mode process that is spawned will load its malicious DLL, ResN32.dll. It does this by creating the following Registry keys: HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\AppInit_DLLs – %APPDATA%\Intel\ResN32.dll and HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\LoadAppInit_DLLs – 0x1.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 uses the Skype API to record audio and video calls. It writes encrypted data to %APPDATA%\Intel\Skype.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 searches removable storage devices for files with a pre-defined list of file extensions (e.g. * .doc, *.ppt, *.xls, *.docx, *.pptx, *.xlsx). Any matching files are encrypted and written to a local user directory.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 encrypts collected data using a single byte XOR key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: During the T9000 installation process, it drops a copy of the legitimate Microsoft binary igfxtray.exe. The executable contains a side-loading weakness which is used to load a portion of the malware.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 searches through connected drives for removable storage devices.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 can take screenshots of the desktop and target application windows, saving them to user directories as one byte XOR encrypted .dat files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 performs checks for various antivirus and security products during installation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 gathers and beacons the operating system build number and CPU Architecture (32-bit/64-bit) during installation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 gathers and beacons the MAC and IP addresses during installation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 gathers and beacons the username of the logged in account during installation. It will also gather the username of running processes to determine if it is running as SYSTEM.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 gathers and beacons the system time during installation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: T9000 uses the Skype API to record audio and video calls. It writes encrypted data to %APPDATA%\Intel\Skype.[2]

Taidoor.Name: Taidoor
Taidoor.Description: Taidoor is malware that has been used since at least 2010, primarily to target Taiwanese government organizations. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Taidoor is known to utilize encryption within network protocols.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Taidoor can perform DLL loading.[1]

Tangelo.Name: Tangelo
Tangelo.Description: Tangelo is iOS malware that is believed to be from the same developers as the Stealth Mango Android malware. It is not a mobile application, but rather a Debian package that can only run on jailbroken iOS devices. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Call Log
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo contains functionality to gather call logs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Sensitive Data or Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo accesses databases from WhatsApp, Viber, Skype, and Line. It also accesses browser history, pictures, and videos.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo contains functionality to gather SMS messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Local Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo contains functionality to gather cellular IDs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo contains functionality to gather GPS coordinates.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: Tangelo contains functionality to record calls as well as the victim device's environment.[1]

Tasklist.Name: Tasklist
Tasklist.Description: The Tasklist utility displays a list of applications and services with their Process IDs (PID) for all tasks running on either a local or a remote computer. It is packaged with Windows operating systems and can be executed from the command-line interface. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
