Techniques Used.Use: Tasklist can be used to discover processes running on a system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Tasklist can be used to enumerate security software currently running on a system by process name of known products.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Tasklist can be used to discover services running on a system.[1]

TDTESS.Name: TDTESS
TDTESS.Description: TDTESS is a 64-bit .NET binary backdoor used by CopyKittens. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: TDTESS provides a reverse shell on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: TDTESS creates then deletes log files during installation of itself as a service.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: If running as administrator, TDTESS installs itself as a new service named bmwappushservice to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: TDTESS has a command to download and execute an additional file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: After creating a new service for persistence, TDTESS sets the file creation time for the service to the creation time of the victim's legitimate svchost.exe file.[1]

TEXTMATE.Name: TEXTMATE
TEXTMATE.Description: TEXTMATE is a second-stage PowerShell backdoor that is memory-resident. It was observed being used along with POWERSOURCE in February 2017. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: TEXTMATE executes cmd.exe to provide a reverse shell to adversaries.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: TEXTMATE uses DNS TXT records for C2.[1]

TINYTYPHON.Name: TINYTYPHON
TINYTYPHON.Description: TINYTYPHON is a backdoor  that has been used by the actors responsible for the MONSOON campaign. The majority of its code was reportedly taken from the MyDoom worm. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Exfiltration
Techniques Used.Use: When a document is found matching one of the extensions in the configuration, TINYTYPHON uploads it to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TINYTYPHON searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: TINYTYPHON has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: TINYTYPHON installs itself under Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

TinyZBot.Name: TinyZBot
TinyZBot.Description: TinyZBot is a bot written in C# that was developed by Cleaver. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot contains functionality to collect information from the clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot supports execution from the command-line.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot can disable Avira anti-virus.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot contains keylogger functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot can install as a Windows service for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot contains screen capture functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: TinyZBot can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.[1]

Tor.Name: Tor
Tor.Description: Tor is a software suite and network that provides increased anonymity on the Internet. It creates a multi-hop proxy network and utilizes multilayer encryption to protect both the message and routing information. Tor utilizes "Onion Routing," in which messages are encrypted with multiple layers of encryption; at each step in the proxy network, the topmost layer is decrypted and the contents forwarded on to the next node until it reaches its destination. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-hop Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Traffic traversing the Tor network will be forwarded to multiple nodes before exiting the Tor network and continuing on to its intended destination.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Multilayer Encryption
Techniques Used.Use: Tor encapsulates traffic in multiple layers of encryption.[1]

TrickBot.Name: TrickBot
TrickBot.Description: TrickBot is a Trojan spyware program that has mainly been used for targeting banking sites in Australia. TrickBot first emerged in the wild in September 2016 and appears to be a successor to Dyre. TrickBot is developed in the C++ programming language. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot collects the users of the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses port 443 for C2 communications.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses a custom crypter leveraging Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot collects local files and information from the victim’s local machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot decodes the configuration data and modules.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses the Windows API call, CreateProcessW(), to manage execution flow.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Man in the Browser
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses web injects and browser redirection to trick the user into providing their login credentials on a fake or modified web page.[2][3][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot injects into the svchost.exe process.[1][4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot downloads several additional files and saves them to the victim's machine.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot creates a scheduled task on the system that provides persistence.[1][4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot leverages a custom packer to obfuscate its functionality.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses HTTPS to communicate with its C2 servers, to get malware updates, modules that perform most of the malware logic and various configuration files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot gathers the OS version, CPU type, amount of RAM available from the victim’s machine.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot obtains the IP address from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot collects a list of install programs and services on the system’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: TrickBot uses ports 447 and 8082 for C2 communications.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan-SMS.AndroidOS.Agent.ao uses Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan-SMS.AndroidOS.FakeInst.a uses Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan-SMS.AndroidOS.OpFake.a uses Google Cloud Messaging (GCM) for command and control.[1]

Trojan.Karagany.Name: Trojan.Karagany
Trojan.Karagany.Description: Trojan.Karagany is a backdoor primarily used for recon. The source code for it was leaked in 2010 and it is sold on underground forums. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can dump passwords and save them into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\pwds.txt.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can create a directory (C:\ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\gl) to use as a temporary directory for uploading files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can use tasklist to collect a list of running tasks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can create a link to itself in the Startup folder to automatically start itself upon system restart.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can upload, download, and execute files on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany can take a desktop screenshot and save the file into \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\shot.png.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Karagany samples sometimes use common binary packers such as UPX and Aspack on top of a custom Delphi binary packer.[1]

Trojan.Mebromi.Name: Trojan.Mebromi
Trojan.Mebromi.Description: Trojan.Mebromi is BIOS-level malware that takes control of the victim before MBR. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Firmware
Techniques Used.Use: Trojan.Mebromi performs BIOS modification and can download and execute a file as well as protect itself from removal.[1]

Truvasys.Name: Truvasys
Truvasys.Description: Truvasys is first-stage malware that has been used by PROMETHIUM. It is a collection of modules written in the Delphi programming language. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: To establish persistence, Truvasys adds a Registry Run key with a value "TaskMgr" in an attempt to masquerade as the legitimate Windows Task Manager.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Truvasys adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

TURNEDUP.Name: TURNEDUP
TURNEDUP.Description: TURNEDUP is a non-public backdoor. It has been dropped by APT33's DROPSHOT malware (also known as Stonedrill). [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of creating a reverse shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created Rundll32 process as part of an "Early Bird injection."[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of writing to a Registry Run key to establish.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of downloading additional files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of taking screenshots.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TURNEDUP is capable of gathering system information.[1]

Twitoor.Name: Twitoor
Twitoor.Description: Twitoor is an Android malware family that likely spreads by SMS or via malicious URLs. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Twitoor uses Twitter for command and control.[1]

TYPEFRAME.Name: TYPEFRAME
TYPEFRAME.Description: TYPEFRAME is a remote access tool that has been used by Lazarus Group. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can execute commands using a shell.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME variants can use ports 443, 8443, and 8080 for communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: A TYPEFRAME variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: A TYPEFRAME variant uses fake TLS to communicate with the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: One TYPEFRAME variant decrypts an archive using an RC4 key, then decompresses and installs the decrypted malicious DLL module. Another variant decodes the embedded file by XORing it with the value "0x35".[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can open the Windows Firewall on the victim’s machine to allow incoming connections.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can search directories for files on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can delete files off the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can delete services from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can install encrypted configuration data under the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\ShellCompatibility\Applications\laxhost.dll and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\PrintConfigs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME variants can add malicious DLL modules as new services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APIs and strings in some TYPEFRAME variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can upload and download files to the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can uninstall malware components using a batch script. Additionally, a malicious Word document used for delivery uses VBA macros for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: TYPEFRAME can gather the disk volume information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: A TYPEFRAME variant can use port 127 for communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: A Word document delivering TYPEFRAME prompts the user to enable macro execution.[1]

UACMe.Name: UACMe
UACMe.Description: UACMe is an open source assessment tool that contains many methods for bypassing Windows User Account Control on multiple versions of the operating system. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: UACMe contains many methods for bypassing Windows User Account Control on multiple versions of the operating system.[1]

Umbreon.Name: Umbreon
Umbreon.Description: A Linux rootkit that provides backdoor access and hides from defenders.

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Umbreon provides access using both standard facilities like SSH and additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet

Techniques Used.Name: Port Knocking
Techniques Used.Use: Umbreon provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Umbreon hides from defenders by hooking libc function calls, hiding artifacts that would reveal its presence, such as the user account it creates to provide access and undermining strace, a tool often used to identify malware.

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Umbreon provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Umbreon creates valid users to provide access to the system.

Unknown Logger.Name: Unknown Logger
Unknown Logger.Description: Unknown Logger is a publicly released, free backdoor. Version 1.5 of the backdoor has been used by the actors responsible for the MONSOON campaign. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger is capable of stealing usernames and passwords from browsers on the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger has functionality to disable security tools, including Kaspersky, BitDefender, and MalwareBytes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger is capable of recording keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger is capable of downloading remote files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger is capable of spreading to USB devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger can obtain information about the victim computer name, physical memory, country, and date.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger can obtain information about the victim's IP address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Unknown Logger can obtain information about the victim usernames.[1]

UPPERCUT.Name: UPPERCUT
UPPERCUT.Description: UPPERCUT is a backdoor that has been used by menuPass. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT uses cmd.exe to execute commands on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT can download and upload files to and from the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT can capture desktop screenshots in the PNG format and send them to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has used HTTP for C2, including sending error codes in Cookie headers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some versions of UPPERCUT have used the hard-coded string “this is the encrypt key” for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2. Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has the capability to gather the victim's proxy information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has the capability to collect the current logged on user’s username from a machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: UPPERCUT has the capability to obtain the time zone information and current timestamp of the victim’s machine.[1]

Uroburos.Name: Uroburos
Uroburos.Description: Uroburos is a rootkit used by Turla. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Uroburos is a rootkit used by Turla.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Uroburos uses a custom packer.[2]

USBStealer.Name: USBStealer
USBStealer.Description: USBStealer is malware that has used by APT28 since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with ADVSTORESHELL. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: For all non-removable drives on a victim, USBStealer executes automated collection of certain files for later exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Exfiltration
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer automatically exfiltrates collected files via removable media when an infected device is connected to the second victim after receiving commands from the first victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Communication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer drops commands for a second victim onto a removable media drive inserted into the first victim, and commands are executed when the drive is inserted into the second victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Once a removable media device is inserted back into the first victim, USBStealer collects data from it that was exfiltrated from a second victim.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer collects files matching certain criteria from the victim and stores them in a local directory for later exfiltration.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Physical Medium
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer exfiltrates collected files via removable media from air-gapped victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (“.skr”,“.pkr” or “.key”) or names.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer has several commands to delete files associated with the malware from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer mimics a legitimate Russian program called USB Disk Security.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Most strings in USBStealer are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer monitors victims for insertion of removable drives. When dropped onto a second victim, it also enumerates drives connected to the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer registers itself under a Registry Run key with the name "USB Disk Security."[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: USBStealer sets the timestamps of its dropper files to the last-access and last-write timestamps of a standard Windows library chosen on the system.[1]

Vasport.Name: Vasport
Vasport.Description: Vasport is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Vasport is capable of tunneling though a proxy.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Vasport copies itself to disk and creates an associated run key Registry entry to establish.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Vasport can download files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Vasport creates a backdoor by making a connection using a HTTP POST.[2]

VERMIN.Name: VERMIN
VERMIN.Description: VERMIN is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN can perform audio capture.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN saves each collected file with the automatically generated format {0:dd-MM-yyyy}.txt .[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN collects data stored in the clipboard.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN encrypts the collected files using 3-DES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN decrypts code, strings, and commands to use once it's on the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN can delete files on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN collects keystrokes from the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN can get a list of the processes and running tasks on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN can download and upload files to the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN can perform screen captures of the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN uses WMI to check for anti-virus software installed on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN is initially packed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN uses HTTP for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN collects the OS name, machine name, and architecture information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN gathers the local IP address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: VERMIN gathers the username from the victim’s machine.[1]

Volgmer.Name: Volgmer
Volgmer.Description: Volgmer is a backdoor Trojan designed to provide covert access to a compromised system. It has been used since at least 2013 to target the government, financial, automotive, and media industries. Its primary delivery mechanism is suspected to be spearphishing. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can execute commands on the victim's machine.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Some Volgmer variants use ports 8080 and 8000 for C2.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer uses a custom binary protocol to beacon back to its C2 server. It has also used XOR for encrypting communications.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer encodes files before exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer deobfuscates its strings and APIs once its executed.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer executes payloads using the Windows API call CreateProcessW().[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can list directories on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can delete files and itself after infection to avoid analysis.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Some Volgmer variants add new services with display names generated by a list of hard-coded strings such as Application, Background, Security, and Windows, presumably as a way to masquerade as a legitimate service.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer installs a copy of itself in a randomly selected service, then overwrites the ServiceDLL entry in the service's Registry entry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer stores the encoded configuration file in the Registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentContorlSet\Control\WMI\Security.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Some Volgmer variants install .dll files as services with names generated by a list of hard-coded strings.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A Volgmer variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can gather a list of processes.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer checks the system for certain Registry keys.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can download remote files and additional payloads to the victim's machine.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Some Volgmer variants use SSL to encrypt C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can gather the IP address from the victim's machine.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer can gather information about TCP connection state.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Volgmer queries the system to identify existing services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Some Volgmer variants use port 8088 for C2.[1][2][3]

WEBC2.Name: WEBC2
WEBC2.Description: WEBC2 is a backdoor used by APT1 to retrieve a Web page from a predetermined C2 server. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Variants of WEBC2 achieve persistence by using DLL search order hijacking, usually by copying the DLL file to %SYSTEMROOT% (C:\WINDOWS\ntshrui.dll).[1]

Wiarp.Name: Wiarp
Wiarp.Description: Wiarp is a trojan used by Elderwood to open a backdoor on compromised hosts. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command line interface.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Wiarp connects to external C2 infrastructure over the HTTP port.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can create a service.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can inject files into running processes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Wiarp creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can download files.[2]

Windows Credential Editor.Name: Windows Credential Editor
Windows Credential Editor.Description: Windows Credential Editor is a password dumping tool. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Windows Credential Editor can dump credentials.[1]

WINDSHIELD.Name: WINDSHIELD
WINDSHIELD.Description: WINDSHIELD is a signature backdoor used by APT32. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD is capable of file deletion along with other file system interaction.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD can gather Registry values.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD can gather the victim computer name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINDSHIELD can gather the victim user name.[1]

WINERACK.Name: WINERACK
WINERACK.Description: WINERACK is a backdoor used by APT37. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can enumerate active windows.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can create a reverse shell that utilizes statically-linked Wine cmd.exe code to emulate Windows command prompt commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can enumerate files and directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can enumerate processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can gather information about the host.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can gather information on the victim username.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WINERACK can enumerate services.[1]

Winexe.Name: Winexe
Winexe.Description: Winexe is a lightweight, open source tool similar to PsExec designed to allow system administrators to execute commands on remote servers. [1] Winexe is unique in that it is a GNU/Linux based client. [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Winexe installs a service on the remote system, executes the command, then uninstalls the service.[3]

Wingbird.Name: Wingbird
Wingbird.Description: Wingbird is a backdoor that appears to be a version of commercial software FinFisher. It is reportedly used to attack individual computers instead of networks. It was used by NEODYMIUM in a May 2016 campaign. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird exploits CVE-2016-4117 to allow an executable to gain escalated privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird deletes its payload along with the payload's parent process after it finishes copying files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: LSASS Driver
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird drops a malicious file (sspisrv.dll) alongside a copy of lsass.exe, which is used to register a service that loads sspisrv.dll as a driver. The payload of the malicious driver (located in its entry-point function) is executed when loaded by lsass.exe before the spoofed service becomes unstable and crashes.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird checks for the presence of Bitdefender security software.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Wingbird checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.[1]

WinMM.Name: WinMM
WinMM.Description: WinMM is a full-featured, simple backdoor used by Naikon. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM is usually configured with primary and backup domains for C2 communications.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to search for and capture files on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to collect information on process creation.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM uses HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM collects the system name, OS version including service pack, and system install date and sends the information to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: WinMM uses NetUser-GetInfo to identify that it is running under an “Admin” account on the local system.[1]

Winnti.Name: Winnti
Winnti.Description: Winnti is a Trojan that has been used by multiple groups to carry out intrusions in varied regions from at least 2010 to 2016. One of the groups using this malware is referred to by the same name, Winnti Group; however, reporting indicates a second distinct group, Axiom, also uses the malware. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: A Winnti implant file was named ASPNET_FILTER.DLL, mimicking the legitimate ASP.NET ISAPI filter DLL with the same name.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Winnti sets its DLL file as a new service in the Registry to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: The Winnti installer loads a DLL using rundll32.[2]

Wiper.Name: Wiper
Wiper.Description: Wiper is a family of destructive malware used in March 2013 during breaches of South Korean banks and media companies. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Third-party Software
Techniques Used.Use: It is believed that a patch management system for an anti-virus product commonly installed among targeted companies was used to distribute the Wiper malware.[1]

WireLurker.Name: WireLurker
WireLurker.Description: WireLurker is a family of macOS malware that targets iOS devices connected over USB. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit via Charging Station or PC
Techniques Used.Use: WireLurker monitors for iOS devices connected via USB to an infected OSX computer and installs downloaded third-party applications or automatically generated malicious applications onto the device.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: WireLurker obfuscates its payload through complex code structure, multiple component versions, file hiding, code obfuscation and customized encryption to thwart anti-reversing.[1]

X-Agent for Android.Name: X-Agent for Android
X-Agent for Android.Description: X-Agent for Android is Android malware that was placed in a repackaged version of a Ukrainian artillery targeting application. The malware reportedly retrieved general location data on where the victim device was used, and therefore could likely indicate the potential location of Ukrainian artillery. [1] Is it tracked separately from the Windows and Linux versions of X-Agent.

Techniques Used.Name: Location Tracking
Techniques Used.Use: X-Agent for Android was believed to have been used to obtain locational data of Ukrainian artillery forces.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Repackaged Application
Techniques Used.Use: X-Agent for Android was placed in a repackaged version of an application used by Ukrainian artillery forces.[1]

XAgentOSX.Name: XAgentOSX
XAgentOSX.Description: XAgentOSX is a trojan that has been used by APT28  on OS X and appears to be a port of their standard CHOPSTICK or XAgent trojan. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the getFirefoxPassword function to attempt to locate Firefox passwords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the execFile function to execute a specified file on the system using the NSTask:launch method.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the deletFileFromPath function to delete a specified file using the NSFileManager:removeFileAtPath method.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains keylogging functionality that will monitor for active application windows and write them to the log, it can handle special characters, and it will buffer by default 50 characters before sending them out over the C2 infrastructure.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the getProcessList function to run ps aux to get running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the takeScreenShot (along with startTakeScreenShot and stopTakeScreenShot) functions to take screenshots using the CGGetActiveDisplayList, CGDisplayCreateImage, and NSImage:initWithCGImage methods.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the ftpUpload function to use the FTPManager:uploadFile method to upload files from the target system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the getInstalledAPP function to run ls -la /Applications to gather what applications are installed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: XAgentOSX contains the getInfoOSX function to return the OS X version as well as the current user.[1]

Xbot.Name: Xbot
Xbot.Description: Xbot is an Android malware family that was observed in 2016 primarily targeting Android users in Russia and Australia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: Xbot steals all SMS message and contact information as well as intercepts and parses certain SMS messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Encrypt Files for Ransom
Techniques Used.Use: Xbot can encrypt the victim's files in external storage (e.g., SD card) and then request a PayPal cash card as ransom.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Lock User Out of Device
Techniques Used.Use: Xbot can remotely lock infected Android devices and ask for a ransom.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Interface Spoofing
Techniques Used.Use: Xbot uses phishing pages mimicking Google Play's payment interface as well as bank login pages.[1]

xCmd.Name: xCmd
xCmd.Description: xCmd is an open source tool that is similar to PsExec and allows the user to execute applications on remote systems. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: xCmd can be used to execute binaries on remote systems by creating and starting a service.[1]

XcodeGhost.Name: XcodeGhost
XcodeGhost.Description: XcodeGhost is iOS malware that infected at least 39 iOS apps in 2015 and potentially affected millions of users. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture Clipboard Data
Techniques Used.Use: XcodeGhost can read and write data in the user’s clipboard.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: XcodeGhost was injected into apps by a modified version of Xcode (Apple's software development tool).[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: User Interface Spoofing
Techniques Used.Use: XcodeGhost can prompt a fake alert dialog to phish user credentials.[2]

XLoader.Name: XLoader
XLoader.Description: XLoader is a malicious Android app that was observed targeting Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong in 2018. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Abuse Device Administrator Access to Prevent Removal
Techniques Used.Use: XLoader requests Android Device Administrator access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Capture SMS Messages
Techniques Used.Use: XLoader collects SMS messages.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Microphone or Camera Recordings
Techniques Used.Use: XLoader covertly records phone calls.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated or Encrypted Payload
Techniques Used.Use: XLoader loads an encrypted DEX code payload.[1]

XTunnel.Name: XTunnel
XTunnel.Description: XTunnel a VPN-like network proxy tool that can relay traffic between a C2 server and a victim. It was first seen in May 2013 and reportedly used by APT28 during the compromise of the Democratic National Committee. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: A version of XTunnel introduced in July 2015 inserted junk code into the binary in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel has been used to execute remote commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel relays traffic between a C2 server and a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel is capable of accessing locally stored passwords on victims.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: The C2 server used by XTunnel provides a port number to the victim to use as a fallback in case the connection closes on the currently used port.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel is capable of probing the network for open ports.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A version of XTunnel introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel is capable of downloading additional files.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: XTunnel uses SSL/TLS and RC4 to encrypt traffic.[2][3]

YiSpecter.Name: YiSpecter
YiSpecter.Description: YiSpecter iOS malware that affects both jailbroken and non-jailbroken iOS devices. It is also unique because it abuses private APIs in the iOS system to implement functionality. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: YiSpecter's malicious apps were signed with iOS enterprise certificates issued by Apple to allow the apps to be installed as enterprise apps on non-jailbroken iOS devices.[1]

yty.Name: yty
yty.Description: yty is a modular, plugin-based malware framework. The components of the framework are written in a variety of programming languages. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: yty contains junk code in its binary, likely to confuse malware analysts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: yty collects files with the following extensions: .ppt, .pptx, .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .docm, .rtf, .inp, .xlsm, .csv, .odt, .pps, .vcf and sends them back to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty gathers information on victim’s drives and has a plugin for document listing.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: yty uses a keylogger plugin to gather keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: yty contains several references to football (including "football," "score," "ball," and "loose") in a likely attempt to disguise its traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty gets an output of running processes using the tasklist command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty uses the net view command for discovery.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: yty establishes persistence by creating a scheduled task with the command SchTasks /Create /SC DAILY /TN BigData /TR “ + path_file + “/ST 09:30“.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: yty collects screenshots of the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty checks for ant-sandboxing software such as virtual PC, sandboxie, and VMware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: yty packs a plugin with UPX.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty gathers the computer name, the serial number of the main disk volume, CPU information, Microsoft Windows version, and runs the command systeminfo.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty runs ipconfig /all and collects the domain name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: yty collects the victim’s username.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: yty communicates to the C2 server by retrieving a Google Doc.[1]

Zebrocy.Name: Zebrocy
Zebrocy.Description: Zebrocy is a Trojan used by APT28. Zebrocy was seen used in attacks in early 2018. Zebrocy comes in several programming language variants, including C++, Delphi, and AutoIt. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Zebrocy uses raw sockets to communicate with its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Zebrocy obtains additional code to execute on the victim's machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: After using raw sockets to communicate with its C2 server, Zebrocy uses a decrypted string to create HTTP POST requests.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Zebrocy collects the computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:\.[1]

ZergHelper.Name: ZergHelper
ZergHelper.Description: ZergHelper is iOS riskware that was unique due to its apparent evasion of Apple's App Store review process. No malicious functionality was identified in the app, but it presents security risks. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store
Techniques Used.Use: ZergHelper apparently evaded Apple's app review process by performing different behaviors for users from different physical locations (e.g. performing differently for users in China versus outside of China), which could have bypassed the review process depending on the country from which it was performed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deliver Malicious App via Other Means
Techniques Used.Use: ZergHelper abuses enterprises certificate and personal certificates to sign and distribute apps.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Download New Code at Runtime
Techniques Used.Use: ZergHelper attempts to extend its capabilities via dynamic updating of its code.[1]

Zeroaccess.Name: Zeroaccess
Zeroaccess.Description: Zeroaccess is a kernel-mode Rootkit that attempts to add victims to the ZeroAccess botnet, often for monetary gain. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: NTFS File Attributes
Techniques Used.Use: Some variants of the Zeroaccess Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Zeroaccess is a kernel-mode rootkit.[1]

ZeroT.Name: ZeroT
ZeroT.Description: ZeroT is a Trojan used by TA459, often in conjunction with PlugX. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has obfuscated DLLs and functions using dummy API calls inserted between real instructions.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Many ZeroT samples can perform UAC bypass by using eventvwr.exe to execute a malicious file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has retrieved stage 2 payloads as Bitmap images that use Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT shellcode decrypts and decompresses its RC4-encrypted payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has used DLL side-loading to load malicious payloads.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT can add a new service to ensure PlugX persists on the system when delivered as another payload onto the system.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has encrypted its payload with RC4.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT can download additional payloads onto the victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Some ZeroT DLL files have been packed with UPX.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has used HTTP for C2.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT has used RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT gathers the victim's computer name, Windows version, and system language, and then sends it to its C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ZeroT gathers the victim's IP address and domain information, and then sends it to its C2 server.[2]

ZLib.Name: ZLib
ZLib.Description: ZLib is a full-featured backdoor that was used as a second-stage implant by Dust Storm from 2014 to 2015. It is malware and should not be confused with the compression library from which its name is derived. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to execute shell commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: The ZLib backdoor compresses communications using the standard Zlib compression library.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to enumerate files and drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib mimics the resource version information of legitimate Realtek Semiconductor, Nvidia, or Synaptics modules.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib creates Registry keys to allow itself to run as various services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to download files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to obtain screenshots of the compromised system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib communicates over HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to enumerate system information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: ZLib has the ability to discover and manipulate Windows services.[1]
